Being a person who played the game I knew the plot already but it still made me feel at times like I was playing the game. Sometimes I was leaning forward wanting to hit the action points to break holes in peoples accusations then quickly realized that I was watching the anime, not playing the game. If you haven't played the game then I think you would enjoy it a lot more going into it with a fresh mind. However, those who have played the game understand it more and get to enjoy the anime in a way others won't. The plot will keep youguessing though some parts might be a tad predictable. It'll keep you on your toes from start to finish. I would recommend this to anyone who has or hasn't played the game just like I would recommend the game to anyone.


The animation is spot on like the game but of course they have to make it look slightly more fluid in movement. It's pretty much how I pictured the game would look like if it was more fleshed out animation wise. It holds that unique style that is danganronpa without looking too gmmicky and as if it's trying to play on the fact that it was the game. I loved how when people died they used the game animation and during cases they used the bullets whenever the main character or someone was going to interject. It made me feel like I was in the game again like I said before. 


The story is pretty simple, it's a classic find the killer in an aloted time and if you don't then the loser goes free and everyone dies. it's explained I believe on the first episode. It turns everyone against each other at first but eventually teams start to form which is like what would normally happen. Each person does their best to solve a murder and the murderer does their best to hide it though of course there is always a slip up. If you've played the game you're pretty much watching it knowing hwo did it so that's why I say if you haven't played the game it might be better because you get to enjoy the twists and turns. Though if you did play it you get to see the investigation more flushed out, so it's a win win either way. 


All in all this anime is unique, interesting, charismatic, and will keep you guessing if you haven't played the game. It brings back fond memories of when I did play it and it reminded me just how much fun I had playing the game. The gore isn't too bad since the blood is pink but be careful with that still. Why not watch it and see if you can guess who did it? You'll be in for a ride and a twist you'll slowly see coming the more you progress.

I’m gonna be honest with you: I’m a huge Danganronpa fan. I’ve played all the games, seen all the anime, and spent a lot of time looking at news for V3. So from a fan’s perspective I’m going to tell you all why this show doesn’t deserve the hate it gets from a lot of the gamer fans and why you should check it out. 
The story is based of the first game, where young Makoto Naegi and his fellow Super High School Level friends are imprisoned within Hope’s Peak Academy by the mysterious Monokuma. Obviously the stuido had to cut some scenes and charactermoments from the game in order to make it fit within its required 13 episodes. But aside from one awkward scene during the 3rd class trial it downright nailed the entire story and never felt rushed to me. In fact I would argue that the final class trial was done better here than it was in the game but hey that’s just my opinion. Is the story still awesome and shocking? Yes! The Danganronpa games are popular because of their awesome stories and I think this translated pretty well into an anime. If you want to start Danganronpa but aren’t much of a gamer I think you’d be totally fine starting with this. It hits all the right marks and only made an occasional mistake here and there.


The art style, known as Psycho Pop, is simply beautiful to look at and doesn’t differ to much from the games. There may not be much action but the class trials and truth bullet sequences will blow you away to the point where you might even start imagining your in a trial the next time you have an argument with your pals. The execution scenes stick close to the original game’s and I dare say even improve on them a bit. Its visuals are so unique and fun to look at that you won’t want to look away for a second. I should also note that the pink blood was awesome! I found it strangely beautiful to look at and thought it really helped sell the whole “Psycho Pop” feel Danganronpa is known for.


As for the characters, I can understand why some people complained about this. Obviously with this many characters and with at least 2 dying every trial, they couldn’t tell everyone’s backstory and give them a chance to shine. But for the characters that do it really nails them. Naegi’s still Naegi, Kyoko’s still Kyoko, and the character relationships are still there. Will you get to know everything about everyone? No. But if you want to know more you can always go play the game. There’s only so much someone can do in 22 minutes before it starts to feel overcrowded and rushed, so I give it a pass. They were fun, interesting, and the deaths still hit hard.


I enjoyed this a lot I’d say. It was fun, thrilling, and whether you’ve seen the story before or not it’s still an awesome journey with a mastermind that nobody will see coming. Check it out if you love murder mysteries!


Overall I’d say don’t believe what some people might say about this one. Its a really good adaptation of a game and speaking as a fan of the source material I say it did an awesome job translating it. I’ll see you all next time and welcome to Hope’s Peak Academy. Let’s hope you survive the experience, nyuk nyuk nyuk!

This anime has received much hate; and to those who have yet to watch it the only thing I can say is don't listen to that hate. This is the literal best fucking anime; it is by far my favourite of all time, and after watching it all the previous anime series I had completed looked like complete trash. At least give it a shot, please- the first episode may seem a little dull and the third has a really weird song, but it's weirdness is one of my most favourite things about the series. I would definitely also recommend watching the anime and thenbuying the second video game; best game I've ever played.


Story:

DanganRonpa automatically has a cool story. A bunch of high school students are kidnapped and thrown into a school in where they must kill each other off. The anxiety I can practically sense brimming off of Naegi during the first night was immeasurable, despite him not being the best character. The story is so rich, holds so much mystery and shock but don't even get me started on the class trials. If you're new to DanganRonpa, class trials are where the students have a debate to decide on who committed the murder. If they get it right, the culprit will get executed. If wrong, they will. The class trials are unexpected, slightly comical at times, dramatic and surprising; trust me, I've never gotten one right. And perhaps the best and worst part is that your favourite characters will die.


I'd say overall the story is filled with twist and turns, and definitely a 10/10 in my perspective. 


Art:


Oh. The art. The art is... absolutely stunning. By far my favourite art style in anime. It's bright, colourful, blizzard at times, odd, and overall really beautiful. The characters have big eyes, big hair and distinct features; there is not one character in the series that you wouldn't recognize automatically. In the Danganronpa art style, literally any type of character can be made. It's really appealing to the eye and very pleasant to watch. 


Another thing i really liked was the pink blood; sure, weird and unrealistic. But that's also what made me fall in love with the series- I couldn't even begin to imagine Danganronpa with red blood. I fucking love the weirdness im Danganronpa; it's supposed to be a dark anime, but killings aside it has a rather light vibe. Its not meant to be serious; so don't go in expecting Death Note or Attack On Titan from it.


10/10


Sound:

The sound is just okay; the op is trash and even the ending is that good. Well, that was my initial thought upon first watching it; there wasn't any memorable soundtracks or anything. But, as I slowly got deeper into the series I fucking loved the music. The ending? It's bad, I will admit, but it's beautiful at the same time. Its the best anime op I know of, just because I've bonded so much with the series that looking back at the song just brings fondness and good emotions. Not only that, but the actual soundtracks inside the anime are amazing; they're simple, with nice beats and a retro like feel. 


8/10


Character:


How to say this without going crazy. The characters are the absolute best; they all have unique and quirky personalities that make them easily distinguishable. They're likeable, charming and at times comical and dramatic; each character is perfectly crafted and has layers upon layers of depth. While they may seem simple on the outside, once you grasp the character you'll never look away... These are the type of characters that haunt you for months and months to come. I advise if you're new to the series to pay lots of attention to their personalities, their vibes, mannerisms, greetings, speech and really everything about them. Danganronpa essentially takes all the stereotypes and puts it into an anime that appears cliche but is probably the farthest from that. 


10/10, and after playing the second game you will understand what true beauty is if you don't know already. 


Enjoyment:

An obvious 10/10 I think. It's nice and short, simple yet so complicated and very mysterious; you're constantly guessing but at the same time enjoying the characters and animation. And when you think you like that character, well too bad they're dead; there are even some characters that you will like after they've already died. It's not just that though; perhaps Danganronpa's overall weirdness is one of the greatest aspects of it. The pink blood and odd songs you will grow to love; it is all apart of what makes Danganronpa what it is. 


I will also add that the murder mystery aspect is perhaps one of the most enjoyable. It is a great anime for making predictions and what not.


Overall:

A 10/10, higher if I could do that. It's not even just this anime that is nesscarily the 10/10, but the whole franchise that ties it all together; if you like the anime you'll probably play the game and from there you've been brainwashed by the producers forever. But even the anime alone is amazing, and I'm positive it will linger in your mind for awhile. 


Danganronpa is actually an inspiration to me; not only have I gotten actually smarter from watching it, but I've taken such a higher value to life now. Because of Danganronpa, there's so many things I want to do. There is nothing but utter passion for it within my soul, and I see it as a mentor of sorts. Call me cheesy all you want, but it taught me many things including what true beauty is and how deep both characters and people can be. 


I would definitely recommend at least giving it a try; and if you do, have an open mind when it comes to the pink blood and stuff :3

So before I get into this review, I do have to lay down another little disclaimer. Like almost all anime based on video games, I have not played Danganropa. I have seen people play it, though have not seen all of the game. With that, it means that I cannot fully say if this anime is the best representation of the game when it comes to the feel of you playing it, I can only base it on visualization and some of the storyline. 
When it comes to the characters, I am not going to go through all of them. Seriously, 16 characters including Monokumaare way too many to have to pick apart and talk about. Not to mention, sadly we don’t get very much about them as well. I do remember that in the actual game, we had much more time to select our favorites and talk with them, get to know them better and start to have connections. Sadly, the anime seems to be way to short for that as it only follows the main game sequences. We really only get to know Naegi (who is pretty much a blank slate), Kyoko (who is pretty much mysterious), Byakuya (snobby rich kid), and Toko (timid and paranoid). While we do get a little more out of them besides these stereotypes, most of it leads to spoilers that I can’t really speak about. I think my favorites were Toko and Kyoko though as they seemed to have more about them that I liked. For most of the show, I really didn’t like Byakuya at all, thinking he was to snobby and never really showed any growth to his character in actually working with the others.


Sadly, I can’t really speak much on the story without major spoilers, but I do want to talk about something that did tend to bother me a little bit. It was the pacing of the show. I feel like it went to fast. While I understand that not everyone would like a show to be long and drawn out, I feel the show went a little to fast. The format of the show was basically murder in one episode along with searching for clues and then next episode was the class trial ending with them figuring something out, and then next episode was rinse and repeat. We didn’t even get all of the clues ourselves when they are searching around, most of those clues showed up in the trial making it hard for us to guess who did it. The one thing I love about mysteries is trying to solve the show before anyone else did in the show. That plus the fact we didn’t get to know anyone personally meant that it felt rushed. I could have seen it being at least a 24 episode show instead of a 13 episode one.


The visual presentation is very clean and matches the game pretty well. With a game that normally has static character designs that don’t move much, they were able to show the emotion and ‘switch’ of a characters perspective pretty nicely in my opinion. I loved how they integrated the ‘bullet time’ and other small mini games into the show but the word mini game felt as though it went a little to fast. I understand as an anime, it shouldn’t take very long so not to bore the player, but we also probably could serve a bit better if they had Naegi talk a tiny bit then. They also kept the death sequences almost exact to the gameplay; it was as though they just took the cut scenes from the game for it.


The voice acting was very well done for most of the characters, the only one I seemed to feel that was not voiced fully well was Junko, though exactly why is something I can’t say within my review. All I can say was that she sounded really annoying to me. I don’t remember if that was how she sounded in the game sadly though, I don’t remember any of their voices in the game. Although Naegi sounded like almost any other protagonist in an anime (sort of whiny in a way but also bland), I think it worked perfectly. In the game he was sort of a clean slate for people to put themselves into the game, an ordinary high school student with no exceptional talent to speak of. Big props go to Greg Ayres who gave a very awesome rendition of the voice for Monokuma. I do remember that in the game, his voice was a bit higher pitched then Greg’s version but I seem to like Greg’s better. He still kept the awesome feel of the character.


While I think that the animation had much of the same spirit as the game (Again this is based to what I have seen of the game), its story sort of lost some appeal in how fast it went. I really felt we should take the time to get to know some of the characters so that their deaths were a bit more heartbreaking. Instead, I found myself thinking ‘Ah… and another one bites the dust, who killed them this time’ instead of having the emotion that you might have had in the game after getting to know them. It’s still a very interesting show to watch, but I still think that it’s no replacement to the game.

As the person who play the game, the anime story is rushed. this anime need like 20+ more episode to tell the whole story.
When there is a case, the anime is telling whole clue fast and i was confused when i watch it. it's not like the game where you solved it and the character must think the logical way. the art, characters, and story overall good. but the enjoyment as former danganronpa player i'm a bit disappointed.
could've been better, hope the next danganronpa anime will not make the same mistake, i never watch the third yet since i didn't finished the third game.

P R E M I S E
A friend recommended this to me back in early-mid August 2013, a month before I watched the anime. See, at the time I knew that "The Animation" meant that it's an adaption to a game. So playing the game is what I did, and well, I decided to spoil the anime for myself. Why? To put it simply, for an entire game to be adapted into 13 episodes, I just knew that the anime wouldn't cover everything the game had to offer.
Because of my experience with Danganronpa, I did not have high expectations for the anime. Knowing that animeadaptions hardly ever exceed its sources, I normally don't criticize it too harshly even now. However, this is a review on the anime adaption as a standalone, and I cannot give it good points all the time just because it has an excuse for being 13 episodes covering an entire game. Nonetheless, it keeps some things I wanted there and doesn't stray far off the plot; more of, it only hits the main plot points of the game.


S H O R T C O M I N G S

Furthering what I briefly discussed in the premise, compressing an entire murder-mystery game into 13 episodes is a risky action - it's quite the "make it or break it" decision. In this case, it's not completely horrid, but it does make things seem rushed and sometimes nonsensical. In the game, there are so many opportunities to bond with the other characters, but the anime had to cut that out because the main plot points take a lot of screentime (a.k.a. the murder investigations and school trials). This causes a lack of a bond in characters for the viewer, and murders suddenly seem a whole lot less devastating. I'm not saying that this anime should've gotten 24 episodes or more, but it should've gotten possibly 15 episodes. Seriously, almost every episode seems rushed; too much is happening, and it's easy to dislike that, for the characters have no connection with me like they did with the game and the whole thing looks dramatic and ridiculous, as if the students don't put up a good fight to the enemy holding the murder rules until the very end, where it just looks stupid. The animation is mediocre, though not downright unbearable. 


P R O S

Despite my rant, there are some redeeming qualities in Danganronpa: The Animation. For one thing, the art is much more colorful in the anime than in the game, even though it can get disproportional. Danganronpa is very unique for the color of the blood, which is a neon, bright pink - I honestly think that's what viewers will remember the most. The executions are closely related to the game, which relieved me that that remained. The characters are unique too, as they have special talents and really cool character designs. The best part to me is the music though; it's slightly haunting, capable of picking up adrenaline whenever it wants, and it's the part that makes you suddenly feel like the next episode will be better. The OP features an English singer, which is always awesome for Japanese creators, and the ED is sung by soraru, one of my favorite utaites.


C L O S U R E

The game is much better in experience, for Danganronpa has a very amazing story and cast of characters, but if you'd like to save your time and not spend so much on it, then the anime doesn't do too bad of a job cutting your time down to about 6.5 hours if you watch it straight. Though, warning, your attachment to the characters will be considerably weak, and you might get outright confused at many points. To me, I feel like the anime adaption had a lack of proper effort put into it, but I don't think that many people will actually dislike it.

Danganronpa: The Animation (Spoiler Free Review)
Danganronpa was produced by Geneon Universal Entertainment, Mainichi Broadcasting System, and Showgate. 
The studio responsible was Lerche who are known for Ansatsu Kyoushitsu (Assassination Classroom) and Monster Musume no Iru Nichijou. 
Danganronpa: The Animation is an adaptation of the manga of the same name created by Spike Chunsoft.
Step foot into Hope’s Peak Academy where a survival game is taking place. Fifteen have entered and only one can leave victorious. Watch along as the students fight amongst themselves as well as the president in order to discover the true mystery of the academy. 
Story: The story takes place in Hope’s PeakAcademy which is a school for students known as “elites” such as the Baseball Elite or the Model Elite. 15 elites are enrolled in this school thinking that it’s just a school for the most talented people in different fields. Unfortunately for the students it turns out to be a false paradise. The school principal, Monobear, begins a game in which the 15 students must kill each other with the last one standing being given the opportunity to leave. The difference between this show and other survival games is that after a person is murdered the survivors conduct investigations to find who the murderer was. Then a trial is held to decide who did the murder. 


Characters: The characters in this show were all modeled on different personalities common in high schoolers. The model, baseball player, biker, nerd, programmer, jock, etc. Each character had a pretty good design and from the get go I was already picking who was going to go far in this game and who wasn’t. The main character, Naegi Makota was quite the surprise for me. I did not expect him to play the role he did and I was very happy with his personality. Most characters have decent motivations for their actions and most of the murders were justified which was good, it would have sucked if the whole show was people just randomly killing one another but then again that is the point of the game.


Mystery: The actual mysteries that the show has are fairly easy to pick up on and you’ll probably figure out who committed the crime before the characters do. Where the anime thrives however is its ability to borrow the key elements from the video game adaptation which came before it and implement them into the show. The pieces of evidence and journals that the characters keep had a video game feel which was brilliant. It gives the viewer an easy to follow documentation of what it happening in the investigation.


Problems: It was too easy to figure out who the murderer was in most cases. I prefer when I am surprised at who did it when it comes to mysteries and the difficulty of the cases wasn’t too hard.


Art: I thought that the animation was quite good. Every character came to life on screen and it for the most part was very enjoyable to watch.


Sound: I liked the opening theme song. Aside from that the music was unnoticeable, it wasn’t great but didn’t detract from the overall experience. 


Overall: Danganronpa: The Animation was a good experience. If you’re looking for a different take on the “survival game” plot then this is the anime for you. I would rate this as an anime that was worth the time.


I’m giving Danganronpa: The Animation a 7/10.

"What do you want to make us do?"
"What I want to make you do? Well, I want to... make you all despair. That's all."
Now that, that sent a chill down my spine as it was being said, just such a depressing thing to say, that's all.
Becoming accepted into one of the most, if not the most prestigious high schools in the country by sheer luck, what could go wrong? Well, most likely everything, to be honest. So much for being classified as the Ultimate Lucky student, Makoto Naegi.
As I have been watching this anime, I have been playing the visual novel at the same time,mainly because I was very curious to see how each would compare with one another. However, the review here is for the anime and I will merely occasionally reference the visual novel here and there.


Story: 7/10


Here, in Danganronpa: Kibou no Gakuen to Zetsubou no Koukousei The Animation, we have a group of high school students, supposedly the best of the best at what they do (e.g. ultimate swimmer, ultimate programmer, ultimate gambler, etc.), and are chosen to attend Hope Peak Academy, an academy that guarantees one success in the future if he/she can graduate. However, if only things were that peachy keen, no?  To graduate, one has to commit a murder and get away with said murder, something that is not exactly sane, nor something high school students should be participating in.


Now the whole concept of murder mystery is nothing new, basically survival of the fittest and wittiest, so it all depends on the execution. What makes or break these type of series is the, so to say, execution of the series. In the case of the anime, we have a typical "whodunit"/courtroom drama plot as we experience the story mainly through the protagonist, Makoto Naegi, as he tries to figure out how to escape from hell without having other people try and kill each other.


 I think for me what makes this experience so special is the fact that we are dealing with potential high school students. Most other series usually deals with adults and whatnot, so it was definitely in a way refreshing, for a lack of better terms, to see how the ultimate high school students would be affected. Other than that, it is pretty much another murder mystery series, a series that I definitely do enjoy watching, but was nothing too different.


My biggest problem with the story was the pacing. I feel like it progressed way too quickly and because of this pace, it was difficult to set up an atmosphere of suspense and we were just barraged with a copious amount of information. However, take what I say with a grain of salt because for a good while, I played the visual novel first, so I kind of more or less already knew what was going to happen, but regardless, when the scenes presented themselves, I still enjoyed them very much. But the plot twists are real


Art: 9/10


Now regarding the art, the biggest difference I think I saw was that the anime was a tad bit brighter, though I will need to make that comparison again. Other than that, the anime stayed pretty faithful to the artwork of the visual novel and even recreates some of them using very similar if not the same art style. The artwork in general looked very crisp and clean when things were pretty happy and whatnot and then looked very grimy and dark and depressing when a murder did take place and not once was I not fascinated by what I was seeing. Such appropriate usage of different art styles when necessary definitely makes this one not an eyesore to see. However, I do question the usage of pink blood, that, I still do not why was used.


Regarding the artwork of the characters, they were very well done and it was definitely easy to distinguish one from another. Their designs are still deeply engraved in my head and hell, even characters who briefly show up are still fairly distinguishable and have somewhat unique design to them.


Yeah, you can tell, I am not very proficient in describing art, all I can say is it pays homage to the visual novel and that it is very nice to look at, very memorable and enjoyable to experience.


Music: 10/10


Now the music is what definitely, for me, brought the anime that one extra step. It definitely pays homage to the visual novel and in a way reminded me of the anime Persona 4 the Animation where sometimes remixes or direct renditions of songs from the source material were implemented. When nothing serious is going on and everyone is having a good time, very playful and calming music plays and when something terrible was going to or was happening, the music suddenly took a dip and was just depressing to listen to. However, the series took a turn sometimes and when something serious was happening,you would have somewhat cheerful and playful music, as if to mock what is really happening and that everything to the mastermind, otherwise known as Monokuma, who I will describe later, is having a great time and that all of it really is a game.


The opening is so memorable as we have an English rap sung by actual Americans with lyrics that are actually referencing hope and whatnot despite the whole series focusing on despair and a lack of hope; not to mention, the opening is very similar to the opening of the visual novel, referencing all the characters and whatnot and scenes present in the series. The opening sounds like as if there is really hope, but is that true? Who knows, who knows.


Regarding the ending, I love how they decided to employ the utaite Soraru. For those who are fans of utaite, you will understand how amazing something like this is. An utaite is pretty much a person who covers songs, mainly, but not limited to, Vocaloid songs and post them on Nico Nico Douga, probably the most popular Japanese video sharing website, very similar to YouTube. But that aside, the ending is memorable in the sense that is has very retro theme to it, kind of like a very old video game in the 70s or 80s, and surprisingly fit the theme really well.


Overall, excellent music that definitely is very appropriate and memorable and even when not appropriate, just makes the situation that much creepier. 


Characters: 8/10 


Oh boy, the characters. Now despite having a multitude of characters to focus and keep track of, many of them are pretty memorable. Each of them are definitely defined by their "ultimate" characteristics and with it, gives them their individual personalities. Every single one of them is very different from one another and it makes it very easy to keep track of who is who. While the anime does not go into detail as the visual novel does regarding each of the characters, obviously due to a lack of time, each one is still easily distinguishable and memorable.


Now what makes these characters so special is the voice actors. They chose some of the best voice actors (e.g. Hikasa Yoko, Megumi Ogata, Nobuyo Ooyama, Chiwa Saito, Kousuke Toriumi, Kujira, Kazuya Nakai, Akira Ishida just to name a lot) and each one of them just absolutely brings their characters to life. It is just very difficult to describe in detail how the voice acting was done, but all I can say is that it is beyond excellent and is definitely one of the selling points of the anime.


And now, the character of interest, Monokuma. He is definitely what makes this show so special and quite interesting to watch. He is definitely by far one of the most evil characters of all time and I think is like another Jigsaw, someone who greatly takes pleasure in the suffering of others and a murder here and there just means more fun. I still have a hard time believing that voice actor for Monokuma, Nobuyo Ooyama,also did the voice of the lovable Doraemon, just let that sink in for a while.


Enjoyment: 9/10


Did I enjoy this anime? Of course I did. Do I recommend others to watch it? If you like a pretty okay murder mystery, go for it. While I do not guarantee a completely in depth analysis and experience like that of Monster or the visual novel itself, it is still a relatively enjoying anime to watch. As I always tell people, I am quite easily entertained and something like a murder mystery, whether executed excellently well or not, is still a joy for me to watch. Even knowing what was going to happen, it was because of the excellent execution that made the series still quite enjoyable to experience a second time. The music is golden, the artwork is very appropriate, the characters are all memorable and distinct, and with a pretty entertaining story, I do think this is a series that the average user can enjoy; just look past the pretty fast story line and a bit lack of detail for every character and I do think this experience can be enjoyable.

First review and all, I will like to say I never even heard of the games let alone the manga and because of that this anime is a straight up 10 for me. I think that is the entire point of this anime, to introduce people who have never heard of it and change that fact. I'm not even going to explain anything else about why I loved this anime so much. All I am going to say is this.
If you have no idea what the name Danganrompa means, watch it.
If you are a fan of the games/manga, judging from the reviews who are thesame, don't bother.

Unless you played the game from the Zetsubou translation, or NIS translation you probably would think this is rushed and has holes, and a bunch of other stuff. But if you play the game you will realize it' actually isn't rushed, but still has some holes. Now I'm gonna try to do this strictly anime.
Story:9/10
Group of highschooler's forced to kill each other. Hell yeah! Story was pretty interesting for those who like mystery solving. Though the story telling in the anime itself was awful. Episode 1 nothing really happened while episode 2 too much happened. Pacing was poorly done. But sadly the problem is thisanime had a budget that they could pass, and with a slow beginning like that nobody was gonna watch it. I only watched it cause I saw someone die in the first five seconds, and I liked the opening song. It gets me motivated.


Art: 8/10

A lot of people hate on the whole pink blood thing, but I don't actually. Dangan Ronpa isn't a happy go lucky thing. The whole thing is actually pretty dark if you know what all happened besides what the anime, and Dangan Ronpa 1 showed. I believe the pink blood was used to put a happy face on a darker subject. Kinda like joking about a friends puppy dying. Sad subject so you try to make light of it. Besides that whatever the exacutions, and stuff don't really matter. Kinda like the Persona games. Cut scene everyone is drawn differently, nobody says anything about that!


Sound:9/10

Tooken directly from the game so yeah. Opening and ending though were both nice like I mentioned. I actually think this is the first time I mentioned opening and endings in my reviews. I usually only mention background music. I need to remember to do this. Anyway Soraru was awesome with the ending, and the full version of the opening is much better. Though I don't know why they decided on rap music in the opening. Like the ending was kinda 8-bit which the game has pixel character's quite a bit.


Characters:9/10

Unless you play the game, and have the abililty to truly appreciate someones quirks, and personality you probably would disagree with me. Kinda like SDR2 Koizumi how everyone hates her. I love her. Dangan Ronpa games have casts of truly interesting characters. Most of them are misunderstood by both the rest of the cast, and fans. Even Naegi is pretty interesting despite being a stock character. I can't show a example without spoiler's but there's several blogs based around character defense, and stuff.


Overall:5/10

Dangan Ronpa is my favorite game so far. So bluntly.... Screw the anime play the game.


(Edit: When I say "screw the anime" I mean that if you have the means to obtain Dangan Ronpa by vita, or psp emulator don't watch the anime, unless you want to make a comparision. Since this was probably made just to get the game know if your already interested just play the game. Dangan Ronpa was one of the best selling games in Japan when it came out so they probably could have made a better one with the proceeds. The adaption is rushed and basically inferior to the original game in every way. Similar to how Persona 4 was turned into a 22 episode anime and all the social links were finished in a single episode. Each character has 3-6 events in Dangan Ronpa where none of them are shown in the anime. So the anime is the just the story, and nothing else, because of the time restraint it doesn't allow viewers to fully enjoy character and their relationships not only Naegi's but also others that develope over the course of the game. Also investigations are cut down dramatically not only murder investigations, but also exploring new areas. Without knowing all the clues it's impossible to solve the cases. So you won't fully be able to enjoy the mystery's of the game. Unlike how Umineko, had long periods of discussing a single subject covering only two subjects in a episode while Dangan Ronpa covers the whole case. So when I said "screw the anime" watching the anime is pointless unless you can obtain the game since you can't fully enjoy all that Dangan Ronpa has to offer.)


(Edit: I mentioned that the anime wasn't rushed, however I never went into detail about why, so I'm making this edit to do so. The reason why I don't think Dangan Ronpa is rushed is because the original purpose wasn't to fully convey what Dangan Ronpa had to offer. Since the original Dangan Ronpa game was realized I think in 2009 and SDR2 was released in 2012 this anime was made in 2013. Inbetween the game and the anime is a full 4 years which is a rather big time gap. Around the time Dangan Ronpa finished airing Spike Chunsoft release a trailer for Dangan Ronpa Another Episode, and a teaser for Dangan Ronpa 3. Most likely the anime was made souly to bring in more people. Yeah the people who already knew of it hated it, but I found the anime first and didn't think it was bad until I played the game. Both Dangan Ronpa and it's sequal were high selling in each of their years so why couldn't they have made a full 22 episode+ anime? Because it was publicity to hype people up for Dangan Ronpa Another Episode. So if the original goal was to show minimal story then the animation isn't rushed. I'd say they did exactly what they wanted to do.)

My First Review, and can guys give me some advice if you think that i missed something. Arigatou
			Danganronpa The Animation: Review
Story:
The story in Danganronpa begins with our main character Makoto Neagi, who is attending a academy called Hope's Peak Academy. He wakes up inside a classroom after getting unconscious and has no memory of what happened, the windows and doors are also closed so he can't escape, and he finds out that he is going to meet the rest of the characters inside a gym. After they resemble  they meet a mysteriouse half black white bear called Monokuma. 
Monokuma explains to them that theonly way to to graduate from the academy is to kill one of their classmate. But it is only if the killer doesn't get caught, and all happens in an debate inside a room called Classroom Trial. If they get the right person, he will be executed for disturbing the law, but if they get the wrong person, everyone besides the killer gets executed and the killer are free to graduate.


What I really like with this series is how mysterious it is. And it has a interesting concept to it, killing another classmate without getting caught by the others is so interesing. And it keeps you up to toes, because you might not know who killed that person, and its very interesing to find out who the killer is after revealing them, which most mystery anime isn't that good at, some are but not all. And you get attached to some of the characters throughout the series.


What I don't like however is that they keep mentioning hope and not to lose hope. We knew that since from the beginning, they don't need to mentioning it every single episode. Another thing that I didn't like is that it is rushed, the investigation is like 7 minutes long, and I don't even see the characters bond to each other, which I don't like that much. 


6/10


Art/Animation:

When it comes to art and animation, this get to the top. Because the characters doesn't look like each other like they are twins, many of the characters has an interesting art to them. And I love the art and animation style when they debate who the murderer is. And I love espasially the animation and art when a character gets executed. It goes from 2D to 3D art style in the execution, which I find very interesting. And the 3D art style fits the concept aswell.


But what I really like though is that whenever a person says a word, that specific word will pop on the screen, and later on the main character shoots the word, so you can see what flaw a person said.

7/10


Characters:

The characters is probably one of the weakest parts in the anime. You don't see character bond with each other, the only characters I think you can see bonding a little is Naegi and Kirigiri. The characters has a title that they have which are called Super Duper High School Something, which is pretty interesting in my opinion. 


And since it is to many characters in the anime and I can't talk about all of them, I will only talk about the important ones. The main character Makoto Neagi is the character that always knows the truth by the end of each debate, I know that the series is based on a game with the character you play as in the same game. 


Next up I think is important is Kirigiri Kyouko, Kirigiri is a mysterious girl that you don't know much about until atleast on later episodes, and I find her very interesting because of the mysteriousness, and she is a girl with a calm mind and doesn't panic like the rest of them.


6/10


Sound:

The sound is just your typical mystery kind of show, but the music that most stands out is the main opening, Never Say Never (No its not from 

Justin Bieber). 


The opening gets you pumped up to each and new episodes in my opinion.


And I really like the music when the character are debating and when they are investigating a crime scene.


6/10


The Overall Results:

The story is a bit rushed and that, but the concept is interesing which will give it a 6/10 points.

The art/animation style is very cool and beautiful to look at, and each character has their own personality and art style, and the 3D art style fits the concept, which I will give it a 7/10 points.

The characters is the weakest in the anime because you don't see any character bonding with each other, but you might like some characters like I do (Kirigiri), which I will give it a 4/10 points.

And last but not least the sound, the sound is you typical mystery show type of music, but you get pumped for each and new episodes because of the opening theme Never Say Never (no not from Justin Bieber again!), and the investigation and the debate musics and good, in my opinion, which I will give it a 6/10 points.

Before I begin my review, I want to say that I am not the most serious critic. I only state my opinions in my reviews, and I don't shove false facts down peoples throats saying the show is bad. With that out of the way, let me start the review.
Danganronpa: The Animation is uh... quite interesting, IF it was done right. This was done absolutely horribly. First of all, this anime is THIRTEEN episodes. And the game has over 20 hours of gameplay. Now, 3 ep - 60, 13 ep, around 4 hour 20 minutes. 20 hours = 4 hours, 16 hours difference. You seewhere I'm getting at? Neither do I. But anyway, this would of been decent if it was at least longer than 13 episodes. It's absolutely garbage because of that reason.


Story: 6/10


The story is actually okay, I don't mind it, yet I've seen a couple of other circumstances like this one. Okay, you've arrived at school. Now, if you can kill someone without getting caught, you graduate, and it's only for my lulz purposes. A bear that runs the school says that. THAT is basically the story. The bear of the school makes an announcement once two or more people find the dead body and then everyone investigates and sees what they can find out.


After they have done enough investigating, they eventually hold a Classroom Trial. If they can identify the killer, the killer is punished, also known as, killed. The killer will be killed if they are identified and if they cannot identify the killer, the killer graduates and everyone else dies instead, maybe, my memory is quite shit.


Art: 8/10


The art style is pretty good, I like how for every death scene they took it straight from the game.


Sound: 6/10


It's okay, but I wouldn't listen to the soundtrack if I was bored. I'd be better off watching Boku no Pico if I was THAT bored.


Character: 4/10


The characters are only absolute garbage because of their non-existent development. In the games, the characters had awesome developments and had great contact with Naegi, in the anime, Naegi talks to the killers about two times before they kill someone and then they die. Well, every character would of been better if they had made the series longer and made them have more contact with Naegi.


Overall: 3/10


Despite giving the story a decent rating, this anime wasn't... too great. No, in fact, it was absolutely horrible. I might rewatch it to remember some things that I forgot in this review, but not for fun. If I wanted to rewatch something for fun, I'd probably watch Lucky Star.

The person that recommended this to me really sold it too much. Here i started expecting real goriness but instead i received airbrushed gory. 
STORY: I liked the concept however by the 5th episode i started forcing myself to just carry on and complete it. For some reason it got more and more boresome each episode. They concentrated more on Naige and by the end he was totally annoying with his cheesiness and childish quotes (however throughout they do try to portray them as sophisticated and grown)
GRAPHICS: All i can say is if you are going to do an anime about death and killings, DONOT belittle the act by making the blood pink\n\n
OVERALL: Got to learn to force self to drop shows instead of torturing through

I love the Danganronpa games, and actually, this is what introduced me to the series. After staying up to binge-watch it all night, I found it to be pretty good, albeit a little rushed. After purchasing the game and playing through that, I dislike the anime adaptation. The art seemed messy and the profiles were god-awful, which I could endure, but it all seemed to end too quickly. There was much to explore in Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, but the anime left out some things in which should have been there. I still love the series, and I will for a long time, but Ithink they could have tried a bit harder.

I really loved Dangan Ronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc. It was an impressive game with compelling gameplay and storyline. However, it's anime counterpart definitely under-performed. The anime itself felt very rushed, and trying to fit the whole game into 13 episodes was a challenge in and of itself. I don't have much to say on the art, but it felt choppy paired with the executions, which came directly out of the game. The dubbed cast was mediocre, I was expecting a little more diversity, and maybe some not well known VA's? The characters were beautiful. Each one had a different personalities and I felt a deepconnection to all of them, no matter how much screen time they received. Overall, the characters were well rounded and well crafted. Besides the quality, the storyline matched that of the game. It kept me on the edge of my seat, and was suspenseful as ever. Overall, it's nowhere near the quality of the game. I'd only recommend it if you don't have the system required to play Dangan Ronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc. I was expecting better, and hopefully the anime adaption of the second game (if made,) will be better.

Personally, as someone who hasn't played the game, I enjoyed it. From what I understand, the game is way more amazing, but this anime, from my standpoint at least, was pretty awesome. 
I like the way the classroom trials were set up. It was interesting, and I haven't seen anything like that in an anime before. I also think it was fun to try to solve the mysteries as the story progressed.
Admittedly, the plot didn't seem to be paced very well, but other than that, I don't have any real complaints.

Danganronpa is a great anime. Yes, it is true that the plot is very exploited in anime, the plot of you have to kill people or this people will kill you like in Btooom!. Danganronpa takes it to another level you have to vote the criminal and it has to be in a debate, this makes it more hardcore and more enjoyable but don´t expect to bite your nails with it. Great animation As reference to videogames because we don´t have to forget that this anime is an adaptation of a videogame, makes reference to the 8 bit videogames of the NES. And finallyand for me the most outstanding thing of this anime is MONOKUMA. Monokuma is a great character, in any time you expect a little kawaii teddy bear to be so sadistic and so frivolous, this anime gains a lot of points with Monokuma. This is the only great character the other ones are very... meh...  And finally the most horrible thing of this anime is the main character. Awful, AWFUL.

Story 7: The story was great, so many plot twists and it got you really thinking all the time.  The anime is basically about a school for elite high schoolers that enrolled based off of their skills and traits. 
Art 7:  Art was good and I love the fact that lerche changed the art style during the punishment round. The characters look like your typical anime character with huge hair and eyes and their clothes are crazy.

Once again so many plot twists and unexpected moments that really got me saying, "Wait what!? why that person!" 


Enjoyment 9: Very fun anime and got me thinking a lot. You really have to pay attention to details and hints in this anime.  Lots of funny moments, I really did like the little bear [Monokuma] what an evil little plushy lol. 


Overall 8: I thought the anime was great, my only problem with it is the color blood they chose which made it look more funny than looking like blood. I do recommend for you guys to watch it if you are reading this. 


Thanks for reading :)

I'd like to say that this is my first review and I am not a good critiquer, but I hope this helps!
First of all, if you didn't know, this anime is based off the Dangan Ronpa 1: Trigger Happy Havoc game, and is a faster version of what happens. I played the game some time before I watched the anime, and I was slightly satisfied.
Story: 7
The story is pretty much the same as the game, which is about 15 students who are trapped in a school that they were invited to join and just step foot in, Hope's Peak Academy. A killing game starts andthe students have to find the killer of each case or all get killed, while the killer gets away. This could be kind of fun if you don't know what happens in the game, because you can try to figure out at least part of the mystery yourself. I quite liked the story, other than the fact that it was a bit fast-paced. There were quite a few twists to each murder case and made the story more interesting.


Art: 5

Before I watched the anime, I originally hated the art style, which differed from the art style of the game, which I liked a lot more. But as I watched the anime, I grew to accept it, and I guess it's not bad. It doesn't really stand out, nor is it really bad, so I consider it mediocre. I like the character designs, as all the characters look different and special in their own way. The animation was ok too.


Sound: 7

I liked the music in the anime, as most of it came from the game, and sets the mood well, especially when there's a lot of tension. The opening and ending songs are also rather memorable, but I didn't really like the opening song. I don't speak Japanese, but I think the voice acting was pretty good, especially how the seiyuus could portray their respective character's emotions very well.


Character: 5

There wasn't much room for actual character development in the anime as compared to the game where you could talk to them, but I think that's fine. I like the personalities of the characters, as they are quite unique and related to their talents, mostly. Many people have said this before, but in the anime we're not as connected to the characters compared to in the game, where we got to interact with them as Makoto, the main character.


Enjoyment: 6

Well, since I played the game before I watched the anime, I already knew everything that happened, but I still rather enjoyed watching this. It was rather interesting to watch, to see how the anime would play out the events of the game.


Overall: 5

Perhaps if there had been more episodes and longer investigations and class trials, it would be better. But I think this anime is still worth watching. If you can't play the game, then watching the anime wouldn't be very disappointing. But if you have played the game, then unless you want a recap, I suggest that maybe you shouldn't watch the anime.

It's Like Total Drama Island, but with Murder!
The show is only a quick 13 episodes. Besides the beginning and finale, most episodes form two-episode arcs. In the first episode the characters interact with each other and motives are established while subtly setting up potential clues, and at the end a body is found. The second episode picks up with the students searching the school for clues and meeting at the jury hall to discuss their findings and put someone to trial. I wish I did have a copy of the game, because the punishment sequences are all unique to the killer and their theme orplace in life in a way that’s viciously ironic like something out of a Saw movie. The downside to this being adapted from a game is that whenever Naegi finds a clue it highlights it to the audience like Psyche. Plus before every trial he gets "emotion bullets," a set amount of points he can make to show a fault in logic, shown by metaphorical bullets. It’s clearly a game mechanic brought over to the show, and each time he does it, I expect him to shout "Objection!"


Naegi is not much of a character sadly, in that he is just a generic main character. I guess his strongest defining characteristic is his powers of deduction and reason. The supporting cast is stronger. The 14 people Naegi is trapped in the school with are perfectly distinct in both design and character. Some of them are a little cliche in the talents they exhibit: the doujin artist is an overweight otaku and the business major is an elitist snob. But others are have completely unique talents and personalities, such as "Hall Monitor" Ishimaru, an eccentric stickler for rule following, and Fukawa the creative writer, who has a very dark surprise I won't spoil.


The overarching plot is Naegi trying to figure out what this bomb shelter of a school really is and why Monokuma is doing this to them. Monokuma has a bit of mystery about him as he is a talking bear plush subjecting the teens to these horrors. I found the reveal very disappointing, but oddly I wished the show would continue. Maybe I'm just a sucker for mystery thrillers, but I didn’t want the murder mysteries to end because I enjoyed watching Naegi work his way through them and sometimes have to prove his innocence. There is talk of a sequel, so I am looking forward to what comes next, and I highly recommend you give this a watch.

Danganronpa is an exciting series - there are plot twists and turns lurking around every corner, and the anime preserves those. However, due to the shortness of this anime, the plot is quite compressed and there isn't as much time for the viewer to really theorize about how the story will turn out in the end (although that might be a side effect of binge-watching the whole show over a few days). The trials were also quite compressed and the evidence was only briefly looked at, so the viewer essentially has to wait for Naegi, Kirigiri, and Togami to solve the trial and explain whatthe evidence means. That being said, this adaptation is very faithful to the events of the game that it was based on and it was really cool to see everything all animated out. I think seeing everything animated really helped me understand where everyone was in relation to each other a little better, especially when it ended up being important in the trials.\n
I also really liked the voice acting in the dub. While there wasn't much time for character development, I still really felt for the characters because of how much emotion they showed (especially in Chapter 4, that made me cry!!!)\n
The art and sound were also really good! I still have the opening theme stuck in my head and the music still created that creepy, tense atmosphere that really sets the mood.\n
Overall, I enjoyed the show, but I would recommend watching it after playing the game or watching a let's play of the game, so you can see the plot unfold with better pacing and more character development.

The Danganronpa Series was the best mystery and psychological-themed anime i have watched so far. I really liked it's story and the way that the remaining characters alive didn't give up for Junko's despair evil plan. The art was amazing and to be honest that Enoshima Junko was one of my favorite character, i like her style and her despair pose on certain times. The climax of the story is when they were given the choice to vote either for despair or hope, and i really liked Naegi's optimistic side and his perspective on describing hope. Well i didn't expect less for Danganronpa 3 bothfuture and despair arc.

Danganronpa: The Animation
Amazing anime for anyone looking for a thriller but don't want the same cliches repeated over and over again. People who have played the game may disagree with my statement and they say that the animators butchered the game, so I guess just to make sure you should also play the game just for the experience (Game: Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc). The character development in this anime was not that great since it looked really rushed and some characters were just meh and looked like they didn't belong there but that is only the anime in the game their whole story was explainedwith thorough detail. If people don't like seeing blood but still crave for a thriller it's good for them too since the artist made the blood hot pink to keep the rating of the game away from mature but I guess they continued it one to the anime as well so it would be better on people who take a little violence. The storyline of the anime may seem confusing but the last episode brings the whole storyline together to help you understand. Warning beforehand you will crave for more after the anime ends since it leaves wondering and wondering about the mysterious ending and what actually happened to our main characters. If people like newer art styles in anime this one has a really interesting one it is called 2.5d drawing which combines 2d and 3d art style to make a unique pop art effects.


New Viewers

I won't recommend this anime to new viewers since it won't match their taste, my vision of new viewers is people who just got introduced to anime with Naruto or pokemon so I think this is not for them. If they want to watch thriller anime anyways they should watch something death note


Who would like this

People who liked Ace attorney, Conan or any sort of detective anime would like this since it is basically the same. Light-Hearted people who watch anime for romance purposes etc. may not be interested in this since it is a way different idea. People that like to think will love this anime will probably like this anime more than all the other viewers.


Unrelated Note

This was my first time reviewing an anime so sorry if you think anything is wrong with I tried my best and hope to make a lot of new friends on this platform. Also sorry for the anime being outdated. ＼(^▽^)/


Final Review:


Noice

Before I begin I would like to make one thing clear. Danganropa is a masterpiece. No, I am not talking about the anime but rather the video game/visual novel series. If you truly want an unforgettable experience, I recommend that you buy it. 
When I first watched the Danganropa anime, I knew nothing about the games but that infamous bear-like plush of Monokuma left me no choice but to give it a try. It was a quite enjoyable series. Every episode was engaging and it took very little time to finish. The style was vibrant and unique but fit well within the story. At times,however, I felt it lacked something. I was often left amazed by the cunning writing, only to be betrayed by the brevity of explanation and lightning quick pacing. By the time I finished it, I thought "this was bad yet so good". 


After doing some research on the series I found out about the games and gave them a try. I was completely knocked off my feet with the brilliance of them. Whatever the anime lacked I found in them. The animation was superb, the use of sound was emotionally euphoric, the characters became my brothers, and the writing was inventive. With that said I am grateful to the anime for introducing me to such a great series. Should you watch it? Absolutely, it's an enjoyable series and even if you think the quality is poor you'll still love it for what it is. Should you play the games? Yes! Yes! Yes! The games are original, ingenious, and unlike the anime a production piece of the highest caliber. 


If you got this far, thanks for reading :)

This anime has it's up and downs of course like any artistic material does. Some of the characters are just thrown in there to purely push the story forward. Some of the characters that stick around for the long run are interesting but at the end of the day, they are there to push the story/plot forward. The story can also be a little bit confusing if you are not paying attention (idk if that was just me though). 
What really made me like this anime is art style. Panning from traditional looking anime to 3D violent and I mean violent death scenes are amazing.I also thought it was interesting that the blood in this is purple/pink not red (obviously to keep a lower rating).\n\n
This anime is worth a watch it is interesting and sort of reminds me of the board game Clue.

I am a huge fan of the Danganronpa world, I played the first game before I watched the anime. Love all of the characters in their own ways but the anime just felt rushed and there was no character development. I would say that it is a good stepping stone to get you into the games but do not rely on it for anything important character wise. 
The story itself is so unique but the anime strips the excitement away. I feel like some things are meant to stay a game, it allows more character development and more interaction with the characters. For example, inthe game, there are report cards and you can interact with the characters to get to know a character more. I understand why they didn't include this in the anime because it would take away from the story. The anime cuts down the days that they are in the school, for example, in the game, there are three days between the first murder and one day in the game.\n
I would recommend playing the game first because watching the anime takes away the shock factor because it goes through the story so fast.

I really started this annime thinking I will have a good moment but gosh, I do not understand how this can have this hight evaluation right now.  Characters are flat and stupid which is the worst when you whant to put some drama by killing your characters and make them solve problems.
