Such a disapointment from a good idie.

DISCLAIMER: This is coming from someone who has played the game.
Danganronpa is a very popular Visual Novel mixed with puzzle and adventure.
Because it was so popular, they thought they'd make an anime, so that you could watch Makoto solve the mysteries on your TV screen.
Today I am going to review Danganronpa: Kibou no Gakuen to Zetsubou no Koukousei The Animation, one of my most favorite game series and anime.
Story: 9/10
The story follows Makoto Naegi, who gets chosen to attend the elite High School, Hopes Peak Academy, where only the people, who are the best in their field, for example cooking or swimming, are taken. Butall takes a turn to the bad, because the students have to kill each other to get outside. The story is very interesting and makes you want to know what's the purpose of the game.

The only problem I can see in the story, is that it is too rushed. You don't get to see much of the investigations and there is not much character development, but I'll get to that later. But overall, I really enjoyed the story and how it turned out.


Art: 10/10

I really enjoyed the art. I have never seen an anime drawn like this.

It had a very colorful style and the way they handled the blood was also really cool. I liked how they handled the class trial. they made it look a little like the game. 


Sound: 10/10

This must be one of my most favorite soundtracks. It fits perfectly to the story and characters and gives you a mysterious feeling. 

The opening was OK, but I wouldn't want to listen to it again. It didn't fit very good to the theme the story was giving us.

 The ending however, was extremely good and one of my most favorite ending songs. It fit perfectly to the story and gave you the feeling of wanting more.


Characters: 8/10

I think the biggest problem with this series are the characters. Not because their annoying or stupid or have no purpose, it's because they have no time to develop. In each episode (except episode 1 and a few others), they solve a crime where one or more characters are killed, leaving no time for plot development of the students in the episodes. But overall, the characters were very enjoyable to watch.


Enjoyment: 10/10

I literally couldn't stop watching this series. It got me hooked, even if I knew already how it ended.


Overall: 10/10

It wasn't as good as the game, but it was enough to get me hooked. I really enjoyed it.


For more recommendations, I point to:

-Akuma no Riddle, having the same theme, only that 12 killers are trying to kill one victim.

-Mirai Nikki, having a survival theme, but with more brutality.

-Another, going more in the horror genre, but has a small theme of survival.

-Higurashi no Naku Koro ni, more in the horror/gore genre, but goes into the survival theme in some arcs.

-Corpse Party, has a survival theme, but with much more gore/splatter.  


Thanks for taking your time and reading my review. ;)

usually i am not this divided on a show when i am finished watching it. but this show had so much to live up to and it fails to be a meaningful experience. this show is biased of the first game "Trigger happy havoc." a game that i would call a must play. and the game has i think 27 hours plus of story to tell. to only have 13 episodes to tell this story is ludicrous to be honest. but this is what the fans of the franchise where given and to tell the truth this creates a very pointless watch for anyone whohas played or is planing to play the game.


this show does not omit any of the major plot points of the game which is a good thing. but it does take quite a few liberty's to get them done in a way that dose not take up to much time. i can see why this was done but this creates a very rushed feel that only works about 40% of the time.


the characters don't fare any better in terms of the issue of time. most of the characters that have very little to do with our main Mokoto Nagi also seem to have a very little amount of interaction with the audience. with most of them not even saying much before there death. for example (SPOILERS) in the second episode i think the baseball guy (Leon) kills another character and is then accused of the murder. for memory i don't think he even say's 30 words before this is revealed. this is one example of a character that someone will know nothing about unless they had played the game. if you had not played the game and only seen the show what is the fat guy's (Hifumi)'s favourite thing to do?


dispute these issues i really had fun watching this show but that is not a recommendation. i really wished that this would be great but it just does not get there. and that is a shame. 

if you watch this and you have  a favourite character just don't be surprised of they don't 

get a fair run. 


6/10 i guess is fair for this show.

When it comes to this anime/animation, one's enjoyment will likely depend on whether or not you have seen/played the original game and know the source material. The "Animation" part of the title is not a simple fluff piece of the name, but truly represents the purpose of this series as literally an animated form of the game that gives a certain life to things that were not possible in the source material. 
One of the main issues that comes with that fact is that the show takes a story that could last dozens of hours and condenses it down to a generous estimate of 5.2hours. Because of this, MANY details and charming bits of the game are cut to save time and you rarely get to feel the actual mysteries that take place between each trial. Things happen so quickly that you barely have any time to actually feel a connection with any of the characters and their relationships end up feeling cheesy and fake.


I personally watched the dubbed version and cannot comment on the original voice-acting, but if you have played the original game, you may find A LOT of the new voice-actors off-putting at best and a complete downgrade at worst. The music is also just... cringey. The popular game theme is included but feels like they literally ripped the file from a copy of the game with no remastering at all. The opening themes are also disgusting raps that sounds like somebody on staff was just thrown in the booth and told to improvise. It's just not very good music for a series known for some crazy tracks.


To cover some good things, the art is actually very appealing and does a good job of keeping key features that give that signature "Danganronpa" feel to everything. There are also at least a few voice-actors that sound decent or at least believable despite being different from the originals. If they just had another 12 episodes to work with, this one probably could've been one of the best adaptions out there. Sadly, that was not the case.

So, the thing about this anime is that the best way to enjoy it is to either not play the game at all or go into it after playing the game and looking at the '13 episode' length and take it that it's gonna be pretty rushed. Which it is. 
Sound (7): OMG THE DUB IS ABSOLUTELY HILARIOUS, this is one thing the anime has over the game. While in the game the only parts that are completely dubbed over are the trial sequences, the anime has all these amazing little bits of hilarious dialogue that honestly had me laughing out loud and yet neverfelt unnatural for the characters I knew from the game to be saying. Like one scene where Taka comes out of the sauna after his transformation and just screams out 'THIS SAUNA IS AMAZEBALLS!!' and the line itself is absolutely hysterical, as is its delivery, but it totally doesn't feel unnatural for Taka to say this. The actual soundtrack is also pretty great as most of it is just music taken right from the game and used in the same kinds of scenes. The opening is fun and the ending is pretty good foreshadowing if I do say so myself. 


Art (7): Studio Lerche clearly had a lot of respect for the game they were adapting. Even if the anime was too short to adapt the game perfectly, it was obvious they weren't phoning it in either. They pretty much recreated everyone's base expressions from the game perfectly as well as giving them each character designs that perfectly express their personalities and are also lifted straight from the game. They even took the promo art images from the game and used them in the opening to introduce the characters. They also used the different artstyle the game uses for the execution scenes. The execution scenes are the best animated scenes in the show and just overflow with personality (as each execution is unique and distinct and based on the character being executed's personality) especially the last one. 


Story/Characters (6): The game had a really interesting concept and executed it pretty much as well as they could have. Since the plot twist that comes in Chapter 6 of the game is pretty hard to buy into if you're a scientifically/logically minded person (like me), but it still managed to make me feel some level of loss along with the characters. The anime... doesn't have enough time. It doesn't really have enough time to get me invested in the characters again at all. The best example of this is Sayaka. Okay, so, in the game, you get the entire first chapter to get to know Sayaka and grow to like Sayaka. And it's made pretty clear that your character (Makoto Naegi) does have some level of a crush on her, and then (spoiler alert) she dies at the end of the 'daily life' segment of the chapter. After having had at least four in-game days for her to develop her emotions and so her resolve to escape seems perfectly legit. She almost has her own character arc in this chapter, but the anime kills her off in episode 2, pretty much skipping all of her emotional development and seeming like she just went crazy out of nowhere. Then pulling the 'she wanted to save Naegi' thing out of NOWHERE to make us feel bad since we only really saw a little bit of interaction between Sayaka and Makoto at all. And every death in the anime is like this.


Overall (6): This anime is really fun and really enjoyable, but if you've played the game you need to go in with slightly lowered expectations. It's not as good as the game, but that's to be expected. If I had been adapting it, I would've given the show 25 episodes. One episode for the prologue, then four for each chapter in which the characters, investigations, and trials would all have their necessary lengths to communicate the point. The epilogue is not long enough to require its own episode, so that would just be added to the end of the last episode. 


So, if you like the game, this is a fun time and you will probably enjoy it, even if you'll know it doesn't measure up. If you haven't played the game, go play the game.

Danganronpa is a brilliant and dramatic anime that had me wanting to watch the whole thing in one go. Every episode ends on a dramatic cliffhanger. 
Despite the fact there's a lot of central characters, the majority of them are interesting and engaging. With only 13 episodes, it could probably be quite a bit better if it was longer, but even so it's very enjoyable and has a good plot. 
The animation style looks brilliant and both the opening and ending songs sound fantastic, with the lyrics perfectly matching the plot of the anime rather than being just random songs. 
I know it's based ona video game which has a great deal more content than the anime, and a lot of people who have played the game are unwilling to give the anime a shot. The twists and plot turns are unpredictable and shocking if your new to fandom, but of course you're going to see what's coming if you've already played the game. The anime is based on the game. What did you expect? \n\n
I recommend you watch this anime if you love anime with interesting characters, lots of drama and suspense, and a bit of coemdy thrown in. \n\n
Don't watch this if you're a close-minded person that's played the game first and have already decided you hate this anime without even watching it.

I gotta say, Danganronpa is my 5th favourite anime of all time. The plot as it is is superb, every single character is unique and really lively (except the ones who die... he... hehe... bad joke, sorry), the music in this anime is just amazingly funky. I gotta give this anime extra points becouse how well they respected the game's art-style and animation... I've played the game before watching the anime and... If you go pass major cuts in some parts, they are just the same.I love how Danganronpa pulls that "I wonder who's the murderer!!!" thing so well, you always end up making yourown theories and you even stop trusting people, It really makes you feel like you're a part of this despair!... and lemme tell ya... It's a Super Duper Highschool Despair... wink wink.\n
If you love mystery and you love detective work, watch this thing... or even play the VN! both of them are amazing!

Anime: Danganronpa: Kibou no Gakuen to Zetsubou no Koukousei - The Animation. Or in other words: Danganronpa The Animation.
(Long name, amazing results)
(Somewhat) Short Summary:
The phrase, "Kill or Be Killed" is applied in this anime.
Being trapped in a school with only one way to get out: Kill someone without getting caught. The mastermind behind all of this, knows how to drive people to the verge of despair, by giving them motivations. These motivations make people want to kill others just to satisfy themselves, sometimes it doesn't go as planned.
My Opinion: 
About a week before I watched this, I asked my anime buddy about this anime. Knowingthat I am afraid to watch rated R horror anime, she said, "Don't worry, the blood is pink." \n
So knowing the new information about the pink blood, I decided to watch it. And lets just say, having pink blood is better than having dark red blood because many people die in many ways. \n
To be honest, this was probably the first time I've enjoyed watching a rated R horror anime. It's all because of the pink blood.\n\n
Overall:\n
It was not as scary as I expected it to be. But it has a great mystery factor to it because you think that the killer might be one person but it's actually a different person. \n\n
Recommended:\n
I would recommend this anime to people who like mysteries and thrillers.\n
Not recommended for people who don't like the non-realistic parts of the anime, such as the pink blood.\n\n

Danganronpa, an anime adaptation of a video game. However, this anime would have had lots more potential if it was given more episodes.
The story is basically about a group of teens, with each of them unique in their own field, be it sports, from an outlaw biker gang leader to a swimmer and  programmer. They get locked up in an elite school with no possible way to escape, except one: To kill a fellow student and avoid getting caught. That being said, Dangan ronpa is a good mystery genre anime, including other genres such as light comedy. It is a psychological and criminological animeand if you want to be the new sherlock holmes of 2013, watch this because after watching this, i am very aware that my detective skills have improved significantly, once in a boys locker room in school, a locker was broken and things inside were stolen, i found the culprit in less than a day thanks to this.


The deductive skills involved in the class trials were brilliantly portrayed, determining the culprit after someone was killed involved all the students to participate into a discussion of finding the culprit with a list of evidence and hence using those evidence to deduce the criminal/culprit. If they were agreed by the majority vote to be the culprit, they would be punished severely, and often die. The beginning of the show's class trials had bad pacing and was rushed as everyone had to speak, while people die off, the trials at the end had less people and so the pacing towards the end was actually good compared to the start. Many of the killings were performed nicely and involved a list of evidence that were found by the other students in order to determine the culprit, every time a person died, there will be a class trials, both the killings and the trials were really intriguing and they psychologically develop your investigation skills. 


The art was decent, clear and neat, weird character designs for some of the characters, however it does manage to easily make us distinguish between who is who due to the colors and their design. The animation was fine and neatly done, it was really clear and smooth. 


Another good thing were the executions, each punishment was unique and leaves us with sympathy in the end. However, the drama was not delivered really well and was a bit weak at the start. Don't worry Dangan ronpa won't give you tears.


One of its best qualities is the music. The soundtrack composed by Takada Masafumi is very catchy and addicting, it also matches well with the atmosphere and mood in the majority of the scenes. All of the openings and endings were very good and catchy, although the monobear opening was really random and weird. All the characters had decent voice acting, especially Monkuma/monobear, one of the most interesting and plot-prominent characters in the show, without his seiyuu, he would not give off the same effect for sure. Also, im glad Naegi was not shipped up with the idol girl at the start, as i thought he would since it was obvious. 

Dangan ronpa is not predictable at all to be frank, it keeps you watching and interested, the mystery is so deep and psychologically, it digs into your brain.


On the other hand, there are qualities that ruined the potential of this anime, they were the rushed pacing at the start as mentioned before if you were reading, WOULD HAVE BEEN SO MUCH better with 24-26 episodes. It would also give more time for developing the characters, one of the parts the anime lacked was character background and development. It would make us feel more sympathetic and empathetic if the drama was done properly by inputting development and relationships between the characters. Only about 3 were developed more than the rest, the three being Naegi, Togami and Kirigiri. 


There are many plot twists and it made the show even better, twisting what we thought into what we never thought. 


Although you might get pissed and beat up your screen, this anime is really worth watching, but remember the aim is to become the new badass detective of the century.

I loved this anime, it's not perfect, but I don't see why people would be so rude about it. I understand they didn't adapt the most crucial parts of the investigations for most of the murders. Seeing as the two that had the most in depth that I can think of were the second investigation and the first. The fourth was very rushed. Over-all I loved it, I did play the game, but I don't see a problem with the adaptation.
If I hadn't known about the anime, I wouldn't have played the game, probably.

Ok, so this is anime is about surviving. I didn't quite get your attention, did I? So check this out: in order to survive, you gotta kill one of your pals without anybody finding out you did it, how about that?
The story of this anime is really unique. I mean, mystery murders inside a mystery house, and all that in order to guarantee your survival? That is just downright interesting.
Ok, Ok, I know. "This anime comes from a game", and "everybody says that the game is much better" and all that. I think we should not trash the anime just 'cause it is short andnot as good as the game (which I never played).\n
It is obvious that an anime that has only 13 episodes can't have as much character and story development as the game: as expected, the anime is very rushed, compared to the game, but I digress.\n
In my humble opinion, I think that, in spite of a rushed story, this anime can still be very enjoyable. Actually, I think that for a 13 episode anime, it did pretty good. The character development is not that bad (well, for some characters it is pretty nonexistent), the art is cool and the story, as I've said already, is very, very solid and mysterious.\n
I don't regret one bit watching the anime.

Before I write this review I just want to state that this is my opinion and you may agree or disagree at your own will.
Review:
Daganronpa the animation is just as good as the PSP game. Daganronpa is a psychological crime anime done very well. Let's start with the intro. The animation for the intro fits it very well but the song doesn't what so ever. It's some random rap song which through me way off and didn't really get me hyped to watch the anime. Character wise it the MC is very interesting but he starts off as the typical weak and kinda useless atfirst character but grows to be strong. Even though he is the typical kind of hero you still grow attached to him and want him to stay safe and survive. The side characters are great (that's a first). Each character is a token character (if you don't know what this means look it up) but even if all of these side characters are general token character each of them bring something original to the table. The plot is super intriguing and it's a multiple case anime so you'll have fun trying to make your own assumptions and trying to figure out the case yourself. Also this anime is like a M. Night Shyamalan movie where there is twist after twist but the thing is most of the twists actually fit in the anime or at least make since. All in all Daganronpa is a very well made and intriguing anime and I defiantly suggest if you have the time to check it out.

Not going to lie; I like my dystopian thrillers like everybody else does, and if you don't then you have problems and I am giving you a diagnostic of 'Anime Killjoyitus' a rare but treatable disease for fellow otakus. But unfortunatly, not many are done right. On top of my head the only three I can think of are Hokuto no Ken (Fist of the North Star), Helsing and this: Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc!
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc (or in Japan Danganronpa: Kibou no Gakuen to Zetsubou no Koukousei...not saying that again) is a dystopian thriller with lolicon, horror and even shonen elements added into it.It is probably one of the only visual novel adaptions I quite like, and joins the hall of the honoured like Fate/Stay Night UBW and Persona. It is grim, it is dark, it is grimy but on the flip side it is funny, enjoyable, and it speaks to some of our darkest desires.


Wait, what? I am about to explain myself! Danganronpa is about 16 students trapped in a school by the headmaster, Monokuma (a half-black half-white robot  who (and I quote) is your headmaster and not a bear) and the only way to escape is by killing everybody else. But get found out during a 'class trial' you get executed in the most inventive executions I have ever seen along with some of the best animation to acompany that.


The main character is Mokoto Naegi, and together with the mysterious Kyoko Kirigiri, the stubborn schoolboy Byakuya Togami, the shy, but cold Toko and her murderous other-half Genocide Jill, the fortune teller Yasuhiro and the swimmer Hina try to uncover all the secrets in the school to find out who is the mastermind.


During the series, we see other character like Junko Enoshima and Mondo Owada who we all think might be the mastermind. I won't spoil who it is, but the brain f*** at the end will leave you itching...that is my ONLY complaint. The rest is very well packed; great characters including an anti-hero, a cold killer (who kills nobody...), a perv and a robot bear, what more could you ask for?


I enjoyed it very much, and I can't say that I did not! The only thing was that clusterf*** right at the end...I mean, come on! And now...the pros and cons!


Pros:

- Original, stunning artwork (especially the executions)

- A great cast of characters, who are more fleshed out in the game, but are great nevertheless

- Each episode leaves you gripping the edge of your seat...you really want to know what happens next!


Cons:

-You should really start on the game(s)

- WHAT THE F*** WAS THAT ENDING???

- It is over? :(


Approval:

 - Over the categories of Story, Art, Sound, Character, and my overall Enjoyment factor, I will give it a skip, stream, buy or ++ rating.

I was contemplating whether to watch the anime, or play the game. If you're the same, I'll save you some time. Play the game. The anime wasn't bad, it was a little too fast-paced, in my opinion. I had to re-watch the ending a couple of times to really get it, although that could have just been the translation. I really liked the parts where its obviously a "cut-scene" from the game. The art was pretty cool, and I found those were the most entertaining parts. Following the story and trying to figure out what happened before they tell you, was a lot of fun.But if youre doing that, you might as well just play the game. The characters were interesting, and there was a few surprises. So basically, it's like most other game-to-anime adaptions, where you really should just play the game because the story is so much better that way.

I loved the video game. The game had character, depth, and many exciting moments. This anime took all of the aspects of the game including the truth bullets, trial, and investigations, and condensed them into a quick episode for each trial that did no justice to any of the murder mysteries. I get that you just cannot put that much information into a short anime, but to butcher the plot and detective aspect of the story...it's just too disappointing. You cannot really get to know the characters at all like this, especially when it comes to the first death. It was too rushed; too manythings left out. I don't mind the minor changes; that is expected, but there was more focus on the deaths and the trial than the actual characters. It's like taking Battle Royale the novel and turning it into the movie. It just becomes mindless killing.\n
Overall, this anime was not really enjoyable. It felt too rushed and there was no way to really get to know the characters at all. You just kind of jumped straight into what aspect was important to the trial and that was it. It was frustrating. Still, the animation holds true to the video games, which I enjoyed, and for the most part, everything was very much the same it's just stripped down too much to be anything but mindless killing.

Ping Pong Pang Pong!
 It’s time for a raving review from super university student level dagengarmaster92. A riveting critique of this anime will commence now. Feel free to have a rebuttal for this review by simply visiting the user’s page and pressing, “Submit Comment”, but beware of sudden accidentals such as improper spelling and grammar mistakes as that could result in a null comment, decreasing the power of persuasion.
The rule of thumb is, whenever an anime is based off of a well-known game and if one completely finishes that game prior to the anime adaptation, DON’T WATCH IT! The exception of course applies to mebecause I have had read the online, “LP’s” (Let’s Play) up to Chapter 2 only via Youtube so, I haven’t had the full experience of actually playing the game.


The anime adaptation of the game starts off with the average joe, Naegi who starts his, “first day” in Hope Academy, “hoping” to have a great start to a school year. Unfortunately, this is never going to happen and it ends up with having a circle of other high school students, each having a high caliber of a specific talent (e.g. singing, baseball, gambling, etc), who have to, under specific circumstances, kill each other and execute the murderer in order to succeed. This is one dangerous game that they are playing, my friends.


I will admit that the first 2 episodes had a promising start since it gives the viewers the full story of what is supposed to happen, but this is where I ran into problems when it comes to staying true to the game version. Despite how the anime tries to keep the intent of the game such as relatively maintain the format of the actual trial run (e.g. Naegi actually objecting his friends through the power of words just like how Ace Attorney would say, “Objection”), it falls flat with character development and is very plot driven. In other words, it’s too structured and it lacks a SERIOUS WOW factor especially as it nears towards the end. There were some moments in terms of character development (such as Ishimaru after realizing who the culprit was for the 2nd murder and his reactions afterwards), but unfortunately, those characters end up either dead or executed and it completely destroys the intent of what these characters could be capable of in the anime. In other words, we get to see those most affected by the execution, in despair for a split second and then, they attempt to change themselves and try to seek a greater good (like a form of vengeance or perseverance to keep on fighting), but as mentioned, literally seconds in the execution aftermath, they’re either dead or executed, themselves—a TOTAL waste of a good character! Overall, extremely plot driven and only touches upon the surface of each character with the exception of the protagonist and antagonist anchoring the, “side characters,” to make the plot advance.


Another aspect that quite irks me about this anime adaptation is the execution scenes. After re-watching most and comparing them to the game, I totally understand that the anime wants to keep the integrity of this game, which has a high reputation for sad/awkward execution scenes, the anime didn’t even come close to creating some sort of different perspective for each execution. They could’ve made the same type of execution for each murderer, yet make it distinguishable so that it can stand out from the game version. Unfortunately, the producers ended up making a carbon copy except with some rough animation, which really brought down the quality of, what could have been, a good anime adaption to the game. Long story short: LAZY animation!


Now, don't get me wrong. The game itself is AMAZING and has a great plot that closely resembles Ace Attorney (i.e. Objection!) and Mirai Nikki (12 people who have to kill each other) having a love child, but unfortunately, the anime adaptation doesn't live up to the expectations to the game. As mentioned before, the anime adaptation is too structured and the characters lack any personality or some sort of development and are pretty much used for plot advancement. 


With that being said, PLEASE play the game instead of watching this adaption UNLESS you haven't heard of this game before OR are looking for something that has a bit of thriller/mystery to pass the time.


My actual rating for this anime: 7.3/10.

The survival genre is famous for piquing viewer’s interest. It is a cheesy way to keep the audience wanting more. Though, some might say that survival genres use the same tactics in order grasp the reader’s attention. It is possible that survival genre is scaling off since the last couple of survival genre wasn’t appealing towards the anime industry. The problem is that the main character throughout have an unbelievable amount of plot armor. An example of this would be Btooom!, Sword Art Online and Mirai Nikki. It is good to have plot armor, but not to abuse it.
Survival anime would be characterized by plot,setting, and pacing. Plot is definitely important because there has to be tension built up in order to create a good survival anime. Without a good plot, the story would be unoriginal and the anime would be compared with. This will definitely dissuade viewers and cause the viewers to the ‘better’ anime. Each person has their own interpretation of ‘good’ and people respect that. Setting is also a huge factor in a survival anime. Having a closed setting can create quickly pace events, while having a vast setting can create a wide range of events. There has to be a rising action in order to build up the plot. This is why pacing is also important. If the pacing is slow, most viewers would get bored. If the pacing is too fast, most viewers would be left with questions unanswered. Therefore, plot, setting and pacing work hand in hand to build a great survival anime.


Dangan Ronpa made its debut when the visual novel was released. The visual novel got quite popular considering it was fun, interesting and unique. There were many options given in the visual novel. As the visual novel grew interest, an anime adaption was made by Geneon Universal Entertainment. Dangan Ronpa’s genre are action, thriller, horror, mystery and psychological. These genres are quite popular in most survival anime. It may be a problem that poses on Dangan Ronpa. There have been many forms of media showing these genres in a survival anime. One can say that it is using the plot and creates a new setting. Will Dangan Ronpa be good or suffer in disappointment?


What is Dangan Ronpa? Dangan Ronpa is a survival game where 15 high school students are chosen to compete in. The goal is to kill or be killed. That phrase is inevitably common. The twist is that only one can graduate and the game only bring despair to others. The players can choose to either adapt to the lifestyle or murder their way out. The school is cut off by the outside world and some people would miss their lifestyle outside of school. This aspect is pretty good considering the plot will rise no matter what. In reality, people would succumb to fear and will risk it all to survive. In Dangan Ronpa, there has to be a killer and the killer has to get away with the murder within a certain time limit. It goes through a process known as the court. This sounds pretty ironic because there is a need to keep ‘order’ when a bizarre situation happens. There are always people who break down when they witness shattering event. The court system in Dangan Ronpa is pretty much a jury system. Though, the punishment for getting the case solved wrong is huge. The court system works by the groups’ decision. If the people decide that the person was the murderer correct, the person is executed. If the person is proven the murderer, but wrong, all of the innocent students get executed. This punishment is pretty hefty and most would try their best.


While watching Dangan Ronpa, the anime adaption of the game was moderate. Turning a game into an anime takes time and effort. When it was decided that Dangan Ronpa will be a 13 episode type anime, it was easy to conclude that the anime will be rushed. There are decent anime adaptions of games out there. Decent anime adaptions of games are Amagami SS, Pokemon, Fate Stay Night, EF – A Fairy Tale of Memories, and Steins Gate. There are more out there, but these anime are quite popular considering how well the anime turned out to be. What is shared throughout these anime is that they have more than 13 episodes. The pacing for these anime is great and thus leads to a good adaption. With Dangan Ronpa, there is much information being disclosed in the game rather than the anime. Most anime adaptions from games focus on the true ends. There are certain routes and ending where viewers won’t be able to see. Normally there would be an OVA to view the story in a different perspective or another scenario. For those who want to watch Dangan Ronpa, it is best to try the game first and then watch the anime.


The animation is quite clear. The transition from game to anime is about right. It is excellent, but it is not extremely detailed. The colors are also amazing. It uses beautiful colors as you can see from the characters. Art now have to be appealing to the eye. If it appeals to the audience, then the audience would be interested in the art style. The drawings of Dangan Ronpa are clean and usual. Though, the setting is not as detailed as the characters. The characters have their own type of fashion styles that seems to attract viewers. Their style of fashion can range from gothic Lolita to school uniforms. Also, cinematic plays a big role in a survival anime. It is pretty symbolic due to the fact that it emphasizes on the main point. Cinematic also add more tension to the scenes.


The audio are about average. It doesn’t seem very fancy and appealing. It doesn’t give off an eerie feel, but makes the viewers curious. The audio should have been more dark and gloomy. Throughout the anime, sounds are specific though. The sounds made are there to appeal towards the audience and senses that something drastic happened. The voice actors and actress did an awesome job in conveying the characters during certain events. What is also interesting was that the Monobear’s voice actor is the voice actor of Doraemon. He is Nobuyo Ooyama. Although this anime is categorized as a horror anime, most would say that it is not frightfully shocking.


The characters made in Dangan Ronpa were plain. These characters have famous tropes that allow the author to easily write the storyboard. Although the characters were generic, they have a huge impact on the storyboard. Since it is a survival genre, some people tend to favor a character throughout the story. The ability of making a character based on popular trends makes it easier for the audience to enjoy these characters. The character development throughout the story is alright. The game was to adapt living without the ‘outside world’ or murder and get out of the school. Those two options are difficult because both of options leave the characters with guilt.


Throughout the anime, Dangan Ronpa was rushed and could have been better. The anime focused on the true ends (best ending that the game offered) and missed out on many information. Although Dangan Ronpa was rushed, it is possible that the visual novel grew more sales considering that the game was better. Dangan Ronpa is a survival anime, but it did not fit the role perfectly. There are unanswered questions throughout the anime. The fact that it was rushed ruins the pacing. Since the pacing was ruined, the setting and plot couldn’t comprehend well. In the end, Dangan Ronpa could appeal neither the survival genre nor the anime industry.

I've seen loads of reviews comparing it to the source material. I, however, won't be doing that initially. Instead, I'm doing most of this review separate from the game version. After having played the game and watched the anime, I know there's going to be a lot of similarities between the two.
STORY:
 The story wasn't what I was expecting, after hearing my 12-year-old step-brother obsess with it! However, even though I'm not a fan of most murder mystery shows, this intrigued me a lot.
ART:
 There's a huge contrast in art from the main parts and the executions. It doesn't do much to deter from thestory. The blood is pink, supposedly for censorship reasons (I have no idea why), but that just makes it interesting.


SOUND:


 I do love the soundtrack to this anime. And the opening themes are catchy as hell - yes, including the Monokuma one.


CHARACTER:

 With it only being 13 episodes, of course you're not going to get a whole lot of character development in that short time. However, going over the top with character development, especially early on, is kinda annoying.


ENJOYMENT:

 I did enjoy this quite a bit. 


And now to compare it with the game: of course it isn't going to be as good. A lot of character development has gone, and certain things were done at different times. But that doesn't make it a bad anime! What else can you do with 13 episodes?

【 The following is a review of : Danganronpa: The Animation, Danganronpa 3: The End of Kibougamine Gakuen - Mirai-hen, Danganronpa 3: The End of Kibougamine Gakuen - Zetsubou-hen, and Danganronpa 3: The End of Kibougamine Gakuen - Kibou-hen 】
Warning: this review is written by a person who has not played the games, these opinions are purely based on the  anime alone! So, to begin with, Danganronpa is a very fascinating idea and the characters are written in a very unique way. I have read online that the characters are expressed better in the game than in the series, but from I’ve seen, thedesigns and the character’s personalities and motives are very distinct.


	• I have had no interest in playing video games, other than visual novels, for a long time, but Danganronpa piqued my interest. There’s something strange and unique about the atmosphere and the uncanny valley that is somewhat reminiscent of Twin Peaks. The first anime series was very enjoyable, but Danganronpa 3 was a different story. 


	• The first series was more or less a locked room mystery with a twist at the end. My biggest criticism was that some of the murders were very predictable and could have been less obvious, but perhaps the game has a different effect with the pacing, since it is much longer. 


	• The execution animations were very entertaining to look at, they were like Madoka Magica’s avant-garde portrayal of witches, or to be more specific, they were like experimental British animations from the 60’s and 70’s. That type of look, along with the pink blood, gives a certain artistic strangeness to the series. 


	• I liked most of the characters in the first season, like: Togami Byakuya, Sakura Oogami, Celestia Ludenberg, as well as many other interesting characters AND the main antagonist. The antagonist in the first series is maniacally evil and you want to know more about her when the series ends, but Danganronpa 3 makes you wish that you had never even asked about her. 


	• I never understood the obsession with Kyouko Kirigiri. In the anime version, she’s a pretty plain character that doesn’t get much development, even in the Danganronpa 3ーwhen her father’s backstory is fleshed out. I don’t know if she has more of a personality in the game, but I felt really disconnected from her in both anime series, but yet there’s a sense that you need to care about her. 


	• The events of the first series are followed by a story that seemed to have promise at the beginning. There’s a gang of villains that have High-School Level abilities like the first group of characters, even Nagito, that acts as the main character’s insane foil and has a similar ability. There is much that could have been explored in this series, but instead we get Studio Lerche shorting out on the budget to a degree that felt insulting to the viewer and lots of shock effect, plus bullshit logic.


	• Let me preface this by saying that Danganronpa 3 is split into two parts, the Future arc, which is the present story, and the Despair arc, which is the backstory of all of the new characters. I have to say, the way that these two arcs are, while watched simultaneously adds breadth to the series and I really enjoyed how well they commingled.


	• Nearly all of the new characters are very interesting to watch, but everything in the story feels incredibly rushed because, as most of you have seen from visual novel adaptations and the like, there’s no possible way to fit all of the moments in a gameplay in an anime series, unless it exceeds a hundred or more episodes, and Lerche barely had the budget to do twenty-four episodes. 


	• The Despair arc is fun at first and gives insight into the caste system of the school and all of the character’s personalities, prior to the antagonist’s meddling, but then the series gets into weird, rushed, torture porn aspects that make the entire thing incredibly empty. It doesn’t help that, in this series, if a female is brutally murdered or tortured, the series seems to take artistic liberties in making it look as sexual as possible. 


	• I get that this arc is supposed to not make you feel good in the least, except for the classroom’s fleeting moments of happiness, but it just seemed like over-the-top, shock-effect shlock that had gratuitous plot holes and little actual seriousness, with the constant silly debacles of despair versus hope, as well as the Blood-C level amounts of violence. The ending of the Future arc is even worse, officially labeled as a special called the Hope arc, in which all of the bad guys come together to help the protagonists and save their lives. 


	• And then they randomly decide to become bad guys again, because the world needs despair? What the fuck? And there’s a character death that is as bullshit as Kyoukai no Kanata. Overall, I’m not sure if the games did it better but the anime really fell from grace. The first series ended in fairly satisfying way, but I’m not sure whether Danganronpa 3 should have ever existed at all. 


	• It feels like there were legitimately interesting characters and concepts that got butchered along the way, the best part of the sequel was the obscure otaku humor, like the scene where it happens to reference Revolutionary Girl Utena and Chibi Maruko-chan at the same time! I rate the first season of the anime a 5/10, the Despair arc of Danganronpa 3 a 3/10, and the Future and Hope arcs a 2/10 collectively.

I have played few visual novels, due to my bad internet that its difficult for me to download a few gigs in order to play a visual novel of X hours. In this case, I had the opportunity to know its animated version that its version in visual novel; Sincerely, I felt very excited to see characters with different designs and personalities, taken out of the stereotypes, as well as the brief emotion of the Class Trials and the pink blood that is one of the most known characteristics in this work. In fact, this anime I've seen a lot of times and I continuedto like ... until I read the visual novel.


I dont have much experience with animes that are adapted directly from visual novels. But it seems that it has certain complications to have to know how to adapt the actions of the characters taken purely from texts, such as knowing how to do some scenes present at certain key moments. A clear contrast with the manga, in which the predetermined actions are already taken on each page, and its only a question of writers and cartoonists having to adapt them in caricature; Even so, its not simple and depends on the ability of the company to do its best.


After all, I'll talk about Danganronpa.


The story revolves around Naegi Makoto, an ordinary student who doesnt have a relevant talent, is bad at sports and just wants to have a normal future with a stable job and a family. However, he receives a message in which he was selected to enter: He chooses only those young people who have a special talent and, as I said before, Naegi doesnt have a talent. However, he entered that academy into a survey, getting the title of "Super High School-Level Luck". Although this, in some way, demotivates the protagonist, he decides to maintain an optimistic thought and decides to enter the academy. Just one day, he seems to feel dizzy and all his vision becomes totally black.


It is there when he wakes up and enters the famous Survival Game along with fourteen other students.


STORY


Certainly, its not a completely original story talking about it being a Survival Game, and that there is a host behind all this. In many Western films we have seen this cliche, as well as in manga works like Mirai Nikki, for example. However, Danganronpa is known for his art and the Class Trials which, personally, is very entertaining to play.


Within the anime, certain problems arise. First, the story is summarized in only 13 episodes. The visual novel, approximately, takes a full day to complete. This detail seems irrelevant to those people who know Danganronpa for the first time, but if you've played the visual novel, you'll clearly notice that detail. Some details may be omitted, for example, some unlockable events to place the most linear story without deviations. But another problem arises: In Danganronpa, there are 5 Class Trials, each one longer than the previous one. Being limited to 13 episodes, this important event has to be briefly summarized.


And most worrying, is when the characters are previously in the Research Phase, since there both Naegi and the rest of the cast find different clues and essential tests before the Class Trials; which is omitted terribly and leaves with holes in the plot. Therefore, within the anime, these tests come to the light of nothing, which makes you wonder where all of that had come from.


CHARACTERS


As for the characters, 16 stereotypes exist within 16 characters. According to what I heard out there, it was made exaggeratedly on purpose as an experiment for Danganronpa himself. However, its very obvious that its to attract easy audience that commonly consumes this. In the visual novel, these stereotypes intersect with the development of each character, their origin and why they are inside the Hope's Peak Academy. This development is available talking and going out with these characters, who at some point will tell you anecdotes and unlock certain useful skills both in the Exhibition Stage, as in the Research, as in the Class Trials. Also, this unlocks some events depending on the answers you give them as the objects that you give them.


However, in its anime version, these characteristics decay towards the lowest.


First, we've the Trinity: The Good (Naegi Makoto), who will be aware of convincing everyone what really happened in the murders; The Bad (Togami Byakuya), who will be aware of obstructing the protagonist's investigation; and the Detective (Kirigiri Kyouko), who will be helping the protagonist and supporting him in the investigation. Above all its Kirigiri who receives greater development, although in the visual novel, she's also the one who has more development in Dangaronpa. I, really, cant deny the good development that these three characters have. But this unbalances the equity between the Trinity and the rest of the 13 students present in this Survival Game; especially when the rest have a very important contribution within the Hope's Peak Academy, although its the least bit.


Second, the rest of the cast. Its protagonism only happens at convenient moments within the anime. For example, when Fujisaki creates the ID "Alter Ego", or Yamada revealing the true name of Celestia. These details are of great value within the anime, and when these characters come to take that role, after a while they end up in oblivion. Of the rest, there's no personal development of each character, and they are only there for the convenience of the plot; a contrast with the visual novel that, including Hagakure, you can know a lot of them. In the anime, everyone is like that idiot.


Third, these ups and downs are trying to disguise the ability of the seiyuus. One of the most important is Ooyama Nobuyo, who was the one who gave voice to Monokuma, making this character the same bear tenderly terrifying and with an ironic humor.


ART


The animation is really poor, despite being colorful and relatively attractive. On many occasions, you can see common errors of the animation, such as strange disproportions when drawing the characters up close, and it is very remarkable if you compare the size of the eyes with the rest of the body. However, we can highlight the scenes of the characters being executed, almost faithful to the original; likewise, the animation used in both the ED and the OP are well complemented with the music used, which I'll talk about in the next section. For the rest, its very poor and it makes me ask why this quality and care wasnt also done in the rest of the plot?


MUSIC


As for music, this point is probably the strongest of Danganronpa. The soundtrack of the visual novel is preserved almost in its entirety, being implemented in the necessary moments of the anime. As for the OP and ED, the first is, for the most part, "Never Say Never" composed by Masafumi Takada, the person in charge of all the Soundtracks of Danganronpa, both in the visual novel and in the anime; and interpreted by TKDz2b. The style of Gangster Rap plus the female voices in the chorus without really triumphant and give you the feeling of suspense to be a series of school murders and investigations. The only exception is the first chapter in which "DANGARONPA" is used, one of the original OST of the visual novel and composed by the same Masafumi Takada; and the fourth chapter, in which "Monomuka Ondo" is composed by Sachiko Kobayashi with the voice of Monokuma (Ooyama Nobuyo) being the protagonist of this "Extra".


As for the ED, one can say that it is the best thing that the anime has, being titled Zetsubousei: Hero Chiryouyaku, interpreted by Soraru, whose quiet voice happens to be calmly aggressive in the choir; An attractive feature for those who are fans of their music. The simple 8-bit used within this song is catchy and is complemented by the 8-bit style animation that gives tribute to the sprites of the characters that recurrently appear in the visual novel.


ENJOYMENT AND OVERALL


Summing up all this, Danganronpa was adapted in a hasty and mediocre way. If you never saw the visual novel, its easy for you to enjoy this anime without knowing the holes in the plot within the characters and small but important details that are omitted within this animation. Its not simply to present the characters and then kill them to quickly say who murdered them, its also to know them and feel compassion for them when a tragic event happens. True, there are open holes in the plot made on purpose to make way for the light and visual novels that would later be published later (There is even a manga that explains how each murder of the original Dangaronpa happened from the perspective of the one who committed it). But there are others that are unjustifiable and, if you were the lucky one to see the visual novel before the anime, you'll share the same opinion that I presented in this review. Otherwise, it will happen to you in the same way as it happened to me, at the same time as with Overlord.


Sincerely, Dangaronpa presents almost the same problem as with another adaptation, but in manga, from an Indie game that I reviewed a long time ago.


If I had seen the visual novel before the anime, this review and score was much worse. But I can't be hypocritical when I say that the anime I originally liked.

Boy oh boy. It's been a while since I've watched such a controversial anime...
Danganronpa! An anime about mysteries, high school murders, and more mysteries. The story follows Naegi, a high schooler who wakes up in a place unknown to him. Later on he finds out that he's trapped in a high school with 15 other classmates, and the only way out is to kill each other, but without getting caught. 
The premise is very intriguing, and it had me guessing for quite a while. But I can't help but wonder why they made Naegi so OP. He seems to solve almost every mystery by himselfwith ease, while under a tremendous amount of stress. That for me was a major issue with this anime and really want to put that first. Aside from that, the characters are all very interesting and there's definitely a wide variety here. But, I really do wish that some of them were introduced better.\n\n
The sound sound is pretty good. The OP is catchy but the male vocals are kinda cringy. As for the art, I really enjoyed it. Some scenes were animated in such an interesting way (without really giving away any spoilers) that I was kinda thrown off at first, but I still really found those scenes to be cool.\n\n
Overall this anime is not for everyone. If you can tolerate a MC who is kinda OP, then I think you'll be fine. There's a lot to like here, and a lot to take in. If you've seen Assassination Classroom, think of that, but the complete opposite.

I don't know how else to describe this anime as the oh so very tragic tale of a anime adaptation of a video game gone horribly, horribly wrong. (Surprise Surprise, here's some spoilers.)
The game was so much better in ever single aspect, the trials, the attachment to the characters as the get death thrown right into their faces, and the masterminds big reveal. I'm a major fan of this series, and I unfortunately have to say that this was the anime that got me into anime, but man did they do Junko wrong.
The directors cut is the biggest problem with this anime, if you lookstraight past the fact that this was the biggest rush job I've ever seen. (Don't look past that, please don't).

I've watched this anime twice now - once before playing the game at all and once after completing the game.
The first and biggest problem with the anime that I have is that it's rushed. The first time I watched it there were parts where I was confused, and as I was playing the game there were lots of "oh, that makes sense now" moments, and that really shouldn't be the case. The anime should have encompassed everything important and not left out any of the details it did. It definitely needed to be a 24-episode series. The class trials and investigations were rushed, as werethe scenes between them where in the game you get to know the characters better. I really wish the anime had focused more on the characters because it would have been nice if the first time I'd watched it I'd been as attached to them as I was when I played the game. It gives the deaths more impact and makes the betrayals hurt more. This anime lacked the emotional impact the game had because of the fast pacing.


That being said, the anime is what got me into Danganronpa in the first place, so it's not entirely terrible. My overall rating would be 7.5/10 but I rounded up my overall rating to an 8 because the franchise in general has quickly become one of my favourites. It's definitely worth watching, but I would recommend playing the game first to experience it fully. I enjoyed the anime more the second time around because it made more sense.


Pacing aside, I loved how faithful it was to the game. The art style, the execution scenes, and the music were all amazingly well done. I'm so glad they kept the stylistic choices from the game.


The characters are well thought out and diverse. I ended up loving characters I never expected I would (Sakura, Asahina, Hagakure) while still loving all my 'usual' favourite character types (Celeste, Chihiro, Kirigiri). As I said before, I do wish the anime had fleshed them out like the game does, but even so the characters are what made me fall in love with the franchise in the first place.


If you happen to be reading this review while not having seen or played Danganronpa, I would definitely recommend playing the game before you watch this, because I wish I had. I'm not usually one for games, but Danganronpa managed to suck me in. The anime is worth watching, but please please please play the game first.


[NEXT PARAGRAPH CONTAINS MAJOR PLOT SPOILERS]


I feel as though the anime could have done the 'big reveal' of the mastermind at the end better. In the game Junko is done amazingly well, so much so that I fell in love with her character during the last class trial alone. But in the anime she's kind of... forgettable. Even as the mastermind, it feels as though her 'craziness' was played down, and this was mostly due to how rushed it was. The switches between her personalities were too quick. The first time I watched the anime I didn't even really pay attention to it because it didn't seem important, but in the game that's a huge part of who her character is. The quick changes did make her seem crazy, sure, but in the game the fact she monologues for a while before changing to another one of her personalities is even more unsettling. Maybe it helped that the game uses sprites instead of animation, so the differences are easier to show, but I feel as thought the anime could have done a better job with them. Her line where she says she even gets bored of her own personalities is treated like a throwaway line in the anime, and is said at the same time another character is speaking so it's easy to miss. This is a huge part of her character in the game and part of what makes her such a good villain, so I'm disappointed the anime didn't use it well.

Now it has been awhile since i watched a horror themed anime. I believe the
last one I watched was Shiki. Now Danganronpa has been getting a lot of
attention over the years and i have noticed its spark in popularity. I see
it all over social media, Reddit, Yahoo Answers, but mostly on
watt-pad.(Author Wannabe) So I finally decided to sit down and give it a
shot and i have to say its not that bad. Danganronpa has a very simplistic and unoriginal yet original story(
I don't know if that made any sense.) I'm a huge fan of murder mystery's so
when I found out this show was a battleroyal type murder mystery I was\n
pretty excited to dive in. Not to mention the saw like atmosphere. Now I have to say the first three to four\n
episodes were really good with capturing that suspenseful and psychological\n
atmosphere. However after that the atmosphere completely becomes dull. No\n
suspense, nothing. Just a bunch of teenagers who have Sherlock Holmes\n
detective skills solving murders. The main theme of this anime is supposed\n
to be a fight between hope and despair. Now this concept\n
was pretty stupid,I got extremely annoyed with the way they were just shoving it in the\n
viewers faces. \n\n
Yes i know your not supposed to lose hope and if you work\n
together you can overcome despair stop repeating it in every episode.\n
Speaking of despair, none of the characters faced any psychological\n
obstacles throughout the entire show. The suspense and drama just felt\n
forced. (excluding the first four episodes) And it bothered me because, if\n
this anime is supposed to be about the characters plunging into despair why\n
not show that. They all remained calm and collected throughout all 13\n
episodes. Also I have to say that the reasons why some of the characters\n
committed murder were flat out fucking stupid. They were all for petty and\n
stupid reasons. \n\n\n
 The only person in this entire anime who had a solid reason\n
for killing anyone was Leon. The execution scenes were just terrible and stupid the only one that was actually brutal was leons. Now lets talk about this fucking pink blood.\n
God i hated this with a passion yet loved it because it was different. The characters were extremely shallow and boring no character development at all. The only four  characters I liked were  Sakura, Byakuya, MonoBear(fucking hilarious)and Toko. That's it, our main character is a generic goody two shoes shounen protagonist who wants to save everyone.  \n\n
The art was fairly mediocre and the only thing that stood out was the pink blood. Wrapping this horrible review up I have to say that I was kind of surprised by the ending I was not expecting that plot twist at all and it was well executed. You can do something more valuable with your time like watching a better anime or reading a book. \n

I will preface this by saying that I have not played the video game, nor seen anything of it. I will not be reviewing this as an adaptation of another version, but solely as an anime of its own merit and nothing else.
-Story
The actual plot wasn't anything special. (Baseline: 5/10)
However, although the overarching story proceeded very slowly, it went into great detail at every step, and the episodes weren't lacking in content despite the lack of plot progression. (+1)
Additionally, I couldn't find any holes in the story; if it were an average anime, there would be something that I didn't like. (+1)
Total: 7 points
-Art
The animationstyle for most of the scenes was neither better nor worse than average. (Baseline: 5/10)\n
The special effects used in the trial scenes were unique and very effective at adding to the experience rather than just being distracting. (+2)\n
However, the clunky CGI in the transition scenes detracted a bit from this. Thankfully, it was used very sparingly. (-1)\n
The art style used in the punishment scenes was also unique and very different from the rest of the anime. Although it didn't necessarily complement anything else going on, it wasn't distracting from the content, and just added another element to this anime. (+2)\n
Total: 8 points\n\n
-Sound\n
The music took a backstage to the rest of the content in most scenes. For this anime, I think that was the right choice, as adding a constant orchestral backdrop would just be distracting, and keeping a quiet-ish background made the music that did play and the sound effects really stand out.(Baseline: 6/10)\n
The intro music was terrible. (-1)\n
The sound effects were pretty spot on. (+1)\n
Total: 6 points\n\n
-Character\n
The minimal greater plot of this anime meant that much of the material would be dependent on good character design. They didn't blow my mind with perfection, but they were solid and were able to fulfill this purpose. (Baseline: 6/10)\n
Some of the character tropes could have been more exaggerated to add to this, in particular the yandere character who was barely so. (-1)\n
Although the tropes might be lacking, a handful of the characters had unique quirks that went beyond convention, and there was good diversity within the anime. (+1)\n
Romance is the most ubiquitous theme in anime, with almost every anime having at least one romantic relationship. In this anime, overt romance was carefully and wisely omitted, which was a very good choice as it would only have detracted from the content. (+1)\n
Total: 7 points\n\n
-Enjoyment\n
While this anime didn't draw me into complete obsession and compel me to binge through it in one sitting, I was never bored and never lost interest. \n
Score: 7 points\n\n
Overall: 7/10
