Dangan Ronpa makes a great original start for a very deep, large and obscure story.
This is the review of someone who, by seeing the anime, got to know the game, thinking the anime was so great. And to my surprise when I played the game and came back to the animation, I felt fairly dissapointed. 
The anime has some hits and misses and here's what I want to point out:
1)DANGAN RONPA HAS SUCH AN AMAZING SETTING It's a story about 15 greatly gifted students that made it to  the most prestigious institutes. Thanks to their talents, they are "the hope" of our next generation.After entering the school, they find out they have been locked in there and the only way to get out is to kill somebody forced by "motives" that the headmaster gives them.

And I think this was ONE OF THE HITS of the anime, since they can explain the premise really well and work with it. Making it into a great mistery/detective anime.


2) THE CHARACTERS: While playing the game, you get to know each one of the characters when they introduce themselves, getting a bit of their personalities and their motives and aspirations, which makes you undersstand their actions later in the game.

Each charater is so unique and with a total different personality, making it my favorite part of Dangan Ronpa.

The animeDOES NOT DO THIS, every introduction is rushed, and you only get to see the superficial part of them. So later in the anime their actions can seem  pretty dull.


3)SO MUCH STORY SO LITTLE TIME:

The game is pretty exptensive, since in them you got your epiloge, six chapters and the ending. Every chapter has three really well done parts to it.

You do a pretty exptensive investigation, get to know the characters in different situations. And a deductive part of it.

The anime, having only 13 episodes makes the plot-line of the story hard to understand at a time, cause a lot of details are omitted and it gets rushed, and I rememeber getting lost at some point.

I think that, a anime of 25 episodes would have been more aproppiate.


4) ARTSTYLE, ANIMATION AND SOUNDTRACK:

Dangan Ronpa has such a peculiar artstyle to it, gorgeous colors and the cutscene animations are stunning to see. The music of the game is pretty average and "backgroundish" but enjoyable.

THE ANIME DID SO GOOD ADAPTATING THIS: Since the artsyle is left the same as the game, it's not a piece of art, but it's so peculiar, different, colorful and refreshing. 

I can say that the soundtrack of the anime is way better and a little bit more remarkable than the one in the game.


OVERALL:

Dangan Ronpa is a great mistery/murder series, that is close to my heart. The setting and the plot of it leaves you by the edge of your seat and it's a great door for a more deep plot to it (that I hope it gets reflected on Dangan Ronpa 3) 

But the anime was a rushed mess of a good story, that takes a lot of good writting and details out of it.


Hope you find this helpful!

(sorry for the grammar mistakes ^^)

This anime had me at the edge of my seat from the very beginning, it was full of plot twists and was very intriguing. I recommend this anime to you if you are a fan of psychological mysteries, you will not regret watching this amazing anime. This anime will have you vying for more because it's only 13 episodes long! 
I really liked this anime because of the art style, intriguing story line, character development, and the way it had me at the edge of my seat. I don't have any dislikes about this anime, this anime needs no improvements because it's a masterpiece asit is.

(There are about three seasons of the show, however, I will not be writing detailed reviews for the other shows since well to me, I always pretty much got the same feel except for the sequels, the story deserves a 7/10 but really not much difference honestly. But yeah, for those of you who follow my reviews, just know that I may not always reviews the sequels to the show. Without further ado, let's get into it!)
Story 6/10
So, Dangaronpa is based off the games. Now, I have played the games before watching the anime. And I'll say, I do feel like they rushed the storya bit. Like, I really wanted them to take their time explaining each case, but it felt like they just rushed right through the entire case. What they should've done is do more episodes and really take their time explaining each case/class trial.


Also, I really can't say much about the story 'cause that would spoil one of the special parts about Dangaronpa.


Art 9/10

The art is nicely done. They did seem to make it look like the game, like I didn't really appreciate that they added a bit of gaming style to it. It's an anime, just stick with an anime style. The gaming bits weren't necessary.


Sound 9/10

The openings and endings are very nice. I just wish they used a different soundtrack instead of the game.


Character 9/10

Dangaronpa is known for having different characters. Honestly, it's a question of taste. I liked some characters and some characters I really didn't care much. Not gonna say anything more 'cause that would really spoil what makes Dangaronpa special.


Enjoyment 7/10

Despite the story flaws, I ended up quite enjoying the anime. I felt like it was a very nice homage to the games.


Overall 8/10

This is not a perfect first anime adaptation, but the sequels were so amazing that I'm actually glad and enjoyed watching this series. I honestly love the Dangaronpa games. But yeah, I really recommend checking out Dangaronpa. It's got a unique premise and interesting story. I recommend starting with the games first, then watch the anime. This anime may not sastify you, but it is worth the watch so that you understand the sequels and I promise the sequels are better! Play the games first that way you know what you're getting into. But, overall, I really recommend Dangaronpa to anyone who likes dark and gritty animes.


Thanks for reading. Let me know your thoughts on this review and any feedback you may have for me. Until next time!

When I first heard about this anime, I had no idea it was an adaptation of a videogame. I watched it, therefore, as an anime, and not as a videogame. I thoroughly enjoyed it, and I can't quite say that I think most of the negative reviews are fair, since a lot of them revolve around how well it matches up to the game. Therefore, I want to provide a review based on the anime alone, and what it does, rather than based on the anime as a game, and what it doesn't do.
The first thing I noticed in this anime (and thus, the firstthing that I'll rate) was the characterization. In the very first episode, we are rapidly introduced to a fairly large number of characters. One of the primary issues I have, in any manga, anime, movie, etc., is telling characters apart. So I was pleased to see that the characters were so diverse, and that it wouldn't be difficult at all to remember which character was which. And yet, the characters weren't empty shells. Even in the short time that we had to get to know them, we saw them form attachments, develop as characters, and grow as people.


The next thing I noticed ended up being my primary issue with the series (and it's a small issue at that,) which was an animation sequence in the trial scenes. The "bullet" animation when we hear "you've got that wrong!" was cool, but it seemed to get used a lot, and I started to want a little more diversity. However, other than that, I had no issues with the animation. Admittedly, I'm not one to focus a lot on how something is animated unless it's brilliant, or terrible, but it wasn't terrible, so I had no problems there.


Branching off of that, I'd like to note that the blood was pink. While some find this annoying, I actually thought it made the show better. Why? Because gore isn't meant to be the focus. I can handle a bit of blood, but I prefer to do without it. This way of coloring the blood, in a color next to red but not directly there, made it easier to handle the intense scenes without (in my opinion) compromising the effect of the scene. And considering how exaggerated the characters look to begin with, it didn't even strike me as unusual except for a moment when I first saw it.


The sound was good in my opinion, but like animation, it's not something I put a whole lot of focus on, so I'll move onto what was my favorite part of the anime, and why I enjoyed it so much.


The story was, in my opinion, fabulous. I've seen people complain, in particular, that it moves too quickly, but I think that the speed actually aids it as a show. Is it a mystery? In part, yes, but not one that we're meant to solve. The game (which I would be interested to play, but haven't yet) may likely put more emphasis on the mystery aspect, but I don't think that's what the anime was going for. I saw not a mystery show, or some drama show where we want to learn every little detail about the characters' backstories, but rather, a story about despair. The mystery and the characters were used as tools and, I believe, used very effectively.


The way the story moves so quickly makes us fear that our favorite character, whoever it may be, could be dead any minute. The way that we don't have enough time to put all the clues together causes us to feel the pressure of the characters as Monokuma sets time limits on them as well. The way that the characters never get a fully developed backstory shows us what strangers these people really are. And while deep characterization, mystery, and plenty of time may have been valuable assets in the game, in the anime, the quick pacing was what made it work. The characters and mystery were well done, but weren't the point of the story.


No story does everything. Some stories may use plot as a tool to help us get to know the characters, and others may use characters as a tool to advance the plot. Both are valid methods of storytelling, though individuals may prefer one or the other. Some stories may even use different methods all together.


In conclusion: if you're looking to find the game in anime form, you will likely be disappointed. But as an anime, (regardless of the game, because it puts emphasis on different areas,) I believe that this was a show worth watching.

Danganronpa Trigger Happy Havoc is an amazing story.
Oh, no, I'm not referring to the anime. I'm referring to the original game this anime tries and fails to capture.
Danganronpa isn't much of a 'game' in the general sense; it's more like a video novel with timing minigames. Meaning most of the appeal of the gameplay is exploring and reading text, both on story, setting, and most importantly, character details, which then plays out as a large murder mystery each time.
Because this is that type of game, attention to detail is critical. You have to feel like you're immersed in the game with the main character. Youwant to get to know the other students you are trapped with, and it goes beyond mere want, you NEED to. It's the feeling of hopelessness the game is about.



So why is this anime adaptation so bad? Sounds great, right? At first glance, yes. The anime looks great and sounds exactly like the game. So far, it's everything you could want out of seeing Danganronpa in an anime, right?


Wrong. And here comes the biggest misstep of all: Condensing a 50+ hour, detail heavy game into a paltry 13 episode series.


I'm not even exaggerating when I say that literally the first 5 hours of gameplay are condensed into just the first episode alone.

I didn't know what was happening in it, and I've beaten the original game, so I was struggling to grasp how anyone new could possibly find enjoyment in it.


Who was it made for? Newbies who wouldn't understand anything at that pace, or fans of the franchise who will loathe it for being so rushed?

I don't think it appeals to anyone.


By the end of the first episode, all you're saying is "WHAT? WHY? WHO?" because unless you pause for the fraction of a second they show character names via on screen name tags, you'll never learn who anyone is, even by the end.

Characters start dying by episode 2, and while both suspect and victim were set up properly in the game, in the anime, it's like "Who were they? Why should I care?"


That's the fatal flaw. You don't care, because nothing is set up. You don't know the characters, the setting, so you don't feel anything; and THE biggest aspect of a murder mystery, the setting and details, are glossed over as well. It's not a character drama or even a mystery show. It fails on both accounts.


The anime can be described simply as this: They wanted to get to the murder trials above all else.

This is extremely apparent given that, despite the extreme time crunch of adapting the story, almost every execution (including the one that has no relevance to the plot, that starts off the series) are included in full, while abridging most  story elements. It's to such a degree that even details in the trials themselves are sometimes pulled straight out of nowhere. A character suddenly knows something they shouldn't, without any setup whatsoever just so the trial can continue.

That is the definition of a flawed adaptation, when they can't even prioritize what prior details to include or exclude beforehand.


If it wasn't already apparent, this anime was simply a cash-in, made by a group of people who did not understand the appeal of what they were adapting. It seems they went out of their way to try and make Danganronpa appear as a style-over-substance anime. But  I implore you, if Danganronpa as a concept interests you, play the games instead. You'll quickly find out it excels at both style AND substance.


Overall, I'd say avoid watching this anime entirely. There is nothing of value here worth your time.

Dangan Ronpa was a great way to start watching anime. It was a great mystery and the characters were very interesting. The art was really good and there were tons of surprises. It didn't take me very long to finish this anime due to the fact that I watched it every time I could. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys a short but good mystery anime

Danganronpa: The Animation was one of the first series I watched weekly as it aired. I had been excited for it many weeks in advance, despite never having played the game. I just found the plot itself very intriguing. And now, after 13 weeks of watching, the series has come to an end. How did it fare overall?
Story: 6/10
Danganronpa was based on a visual novel that I, unfortunately, have not had the opportunity to play. Despite that, I was pulled in by the story very early on. There were so many questions I had about what was going on at Hope’s Peak Academy. So eachweek, I would tune back in in the hope of finding more answers. For the majority of the show, the pattern of classmate killed, investigation commences, classroom trial, classmate voted guilty seemed fairly inevitable, and became quite trite and worn after only a few episodes. However, I started to get a bit more hopeful towards the end of the series. But without spoiling anything, I feel that it just fell flat. The last two episodes were rushed and even confusing at times. The situation changed so quickly in such a short amount of time. Answers were being spewed out at me one by one, yet there was no satisfaction.

There were a few other things that bothered me, mostly involving the pacing of the story. I wish that the investigations could have gone more in-depth, as opposed to having clues handed to us and drawing the connections with seemingly no time to think. As I mentioned before, I haven’t played the original VN, so this is just my take on the series as an anime alone. But my guess is that trying to fit an entire VN into a single, 13 episode series will leave much to be desired.


Characters: 5/10

Overall, the characters as a whole were not much to speak of. However, had they had the opportunity to develop further, they would’ve all had a lot more potential. Makoto Naegi, although being the main character, seemed to be used as a plot device much of the time, used only to correct others in class trials and advance the story. It’s sad, because had he been further developed, he may have had more appeal. Kirigiri Kyouko could’ve shined as well, but much of her personality is kept hidden from the viewers. From early on, she was a favorite of mine, but again, just fell short of my expectations. There is quite a large cast here, and the majority of them fell flat as well. But there were two that I felt were at least worthy of a mention. I really enjoyed Fukawa Touko and her split personality (I won’t say anymore because of spoilers). I found myself laughing every time she was involved. Maybe that was just me, but I thought it was worth mentioning. The other honorable mention is Monobear/Monokuma. Everything he did just threw me for a loop. I never knew what would happen next, and Monobear was one of the main reasons I kept coming back each week. But, despite all of this, the overall cast was quite bland and uninteresting.



Animation/Sound: 7/10

The animation itself wasn’t phenomenal, but the chosen style fit very well with the mood of the series. After each classroom trial, after a classmate was voted guilty, the style of the animation would take a very different turn, something that I can only describe as eerie. It worked very well to set the atmosphere for the scene. The OP was very catchy as well, and I found myself listening to it fully each week. Otherwise, there isn’t much to speak of.


Enjoyment: 8/10

Despite all of its flaws, Danganronpa held my attention throughout. I was able to think about the true meaning behind Hope’s Peak Academy and draw my own conclusions (before they were handed to me, of course), and the show had its moments in which I would catch myself laughing, or with my mouth agape. It was a show I was able to look forward to with each passing week, and I do not regret sticking around.


Overall: 7/10

This is a show that can be enjoyable if you take it at face value. While it had potential as a mystery, it didn’t reach that potential by any means. But by just accepting it for what it is, it’s not a bad watch. If you enjoy seeing the reactions of a bunch of high schoolers in a fight to the death, then you’ll probably enjoy Danganronpa, too.

Ok this is going to be a nice and simple review!

They said the story was a little rush but for me i really did  enjoy this anime, Love the opening!
For the people who was wondering if you should try this anime or not i really recommend you do!

I could’ve written this review without watching the anime. For all its twists and turns, Danganropa works like you’d expect it to. Even the claim that it’s not as in-depth as the game doesn’t feel relevant. It’s a darkly humorous anime filled with hilarious characters. There isn’t much psychological depth, but everyone is memorable and no one gets demonized.
Danganronpa understands why Death Game scenarios work, and what are its strengths and weaknesses. These scenarios rely on a fairly unpredictable out come. We know the main character wins, but not always who will be his final match. The most important part is the characters. Their personalitymodify their interactions, the methods they use and how the ‘matches’ go.


By abandoning any characterization, you’re left with emptiness. All you will have is a show of violence, which can only be entertaining for so long. Thankfully this isn’t BTOOOM!. You can tell by just looking at the brilliant character design.


Every character has a distinct look. No character is allowed to look like another. I haven’t seen a cast with this much effort put into the design. Everyone sports different hairstyles, outfits and even shapes of the eyes. The differences are more than just to tell apart the character. Each detail helps to point to the personality of the character. This is how character design should be – expressing the character using the visuals.


They are not psychological portraits. They are a collection of quirks, but these quirks never point to some realistic personality. The characters are, after all, chosen more for their skills rather than their personality. Normally this would lead to perfect, boring characters. In this guys, the talent points more towards some personality that’s exaggerated and made to feel alive, if not realistic.


It’s not that these are shallow without hope. There is hope for some depth and the show occasionally taps into it, but that’s not how we get to know the characters. We know them like we know our classmates – we know their patterns and learn to laugh about it. Even without the psychological aspect, it’s a vivid, entertaining cast.


They’re so entertaining that even the dullest characters (Who are for some reason the main ones. Someone was taking crazy pills) are entertaining. Neagi and Kirigiri are archetypes without much blood in them. The former is normal and means well. The other is a cold girl who always runs off to the writers, who tell her how to solve the mysteries. They never reach the heights of Fukawa or Junko or pretty much anyone, but they’re a cut above characters in the same style.


The best of them all is Monokuma. He’s the embodiment of the series and why it works. If the premise and the characters don’t look weird enough, we also get a talking teddy bear that runs the school. He treats the violence and absurdity flippantly, as if it’s normal.


Isn’t this how comedy works? It presents an absurd situation where no one recognizes the absurdity. Although Danganronpa‘s story is a mystery, all the techniques are comic. It puts more emphasis on weird situations than a coherent puzzle. The mysteries aren’t exactly cleverly built. They’re messy and require some leap of faith, especially as the series goes on. The final twist is pure comedy.


Good mysteries are more than just predictable. They have an interesting structure and don’t rely just on the outcome. Absurdity is one way to do it. Even if Danganronpa‘s structure is fuzzy, it’s never boring. Every mystery is unique and memorable.


The comedy also works because of its darkness. This is another case where darkness isn’t used to minimize the horror but amplify it. The bear is cute and the academy looks pretty, but it’s a cruel way of life. There seems to be no other solution than dying or killing, and yet the series knows this isn’t a good reason to sacrifice absurdity or characters. Just because a situation is harsh doesn’t mean it doesn’t have a funny side to it.


There is almost something meta about Monokuma. That route is never explored, which is a shame. It could’ve lifted the anime a little higher. Monokuma keeps telling the students to kill each other so he won’t get bored watching them. Isn’t this why you watch the anime? You watch it to see them kill each other. Wouldn’t be boring if the students decided not to kill each other, but just to kill time with each other?


The anime explores this question a bit, but not enough. Extending the time where the characters just being themselves could’ve put these two next to each other – School Life and Mystery – and we’ll have to ask ourselves what we prefer and why.


It doesn’t suffer from the over-abundance of ideas like its sister anime, Future Diary. In that one, ideas came and went. There were a lot of hints they could be explored but then they were dropped. While Danganronpa has these routes, it knows it can’t explore all of them in 12 episodes.


The few themes that appear – despair, violence, friendship – are used to spice up the story. The story is slightly shallower, but it’s also more organized and better paced. I’m sure the visual novel has more ideas, but in 12 Danganronpa manages to tell a hilarious mystery and not get sidetracked.


It’s in no way just advertisement for the visual novel. It’s a very entertaining anime filled with vivid characters, weird situations and a funny mystery. The approach to the genre is different, but better than the common one. It may lack substance, but it makes up for it in being entertaining. You don’t need a lot of episodes and fights that last for hours to be entertaining. You just need characters and situations that are odd enough to be memorable. You don’t need punchlines to be funny, you just to find the funny in already existing situations/characters.


3.5 upupupupupu out of 5 upupupupupupu

This Anime is one of those shows where you watch it even though you know it probably won't break into your highest quality anime list, but you still have to watch it cause it just looks so random and fun with an interesting theme. Danganronpa definitely fails in its character development department, compared to a lot of the top animes, and the story was pretty weak by the end. However, the first episode bursts straight out of the gates, and hooks you into a fun little (lowish quality) entertaining world of stupid deaths, stupider characters, and a surprisingly light attitude. I had a fun timewatching it, and i think most people will enjoy it, but i must admit it was far from the highest quality anime i have seen.

this was my first review

I have never played the game so I'll simply judge this show on its own merits.
With that said, I don't need to play the game to know that this simply isn't very good. It's fun to watch in its own right, and fans of the genre should still check it out because it's short any way but...
First I'll talk about one of the most obvious things about this show, the art style. It's... unique to say the least. All of the characters have very expressive and exaggerated designs, and many of the backgrounds are very stylized. This is especially true when the "punishments" are shown.This gives the show a very artificial look, and whether that's a good or a bad thing is up to you. On one side the art is the thing that REALLY makes the show feel unique, on the other side well... it makes it very hard for this show to be taken seriously. For a show about people dying one by one and central themes of hope vs. despair... the tone's a lot lighter than it should be. I'm fine with a show that seems sort of light on the outside but very dark and gruesome at its core but this show does not pull that off well. Frankly, it's harder to care when people die when the blood is fucking PURPLE.


That's the problem with the show, its plot isn't too bad in theory but it rushes through everything so much that absolutely nothing has the weight that it should. None of the characters are that interesting because barely any of them get much development, and the development they do get is either A. rushed or B. just used as a plot device. So the characters are basically just a collection of cardboard cut out tropes that you barely end up caring about.


And the story itself was... OK. It got kind of convoluted towards the end, some of it didn't make all that much sense, and it was pretty rushed the whole way through. But at the very least it held your attention.


And that's the show, it's the kind of show where you keep watching because you want to see what happens next but never actually get that much satisfaction from the results. The art style is very unique but its over the top when something more subtle might have been more effective. it can be fun to watch at times, especially with the main villain's antics, but if you're expecting good mystery, good characters, good depth... quite frankly you're looking in the wrong place. I think the show had potential to be a deep and gratifying experience, something that seems colorful on the outside but is actually quite grim and thought provoking when you actually think about it. That's what this show completely failed to be. But if there's one thing I can say about it, it was never boring. So give it a watch if you want, but don't expect too much out of it.

This was actually the first anime that I watched. Right from the start, I found it intriguing, full of twists, keeping me glued to it. One episode went onto another, and another, and before I knew it, I had watched the whole thing in one sitting. 
Now, many people say that if you haven't play the game, you will find it hard to follow. Well, I haven't played the game, and I found it extremely easy to follow. I didn't get confused AT ALL, even the more complex crimes made sense. 
In my opinion, the only bad thing about this anime is the lack ofcharacter development. I really wish they had included some more episodes just for viewers to get to know the characters. Especially the characters who die near the start. \n
All in all, a must watch for anyone who likes battle royale or hunger games sort of stuff. Also comes with some great music and characters.

So to start off, I have not played any of the games/read any of the manga, I have only seen the anime adaptation so this is my view of the anime as a newcomer to Danganronpa.
I will cover some spoilers so you have been warned(although by the time I've seen the anime is already long past the hype and relevance so lol).
I also like to start ratings at 5/10 and either increase or decrease from there.
Story: 7/10
I liked the premise of the high school students all trapped with no previous recollections and suddenly being told to get out they have to murder a classmate andget away with it. I thought it was original enough. With the amount of students and episodes it felt fairly predictable, like you could tell there was going to be at least one death per episode, and the episodes delivered. 


All in all, it was pretty good although it felt pretty rushed in spots such as the investigation scenes, (like others commented) and I wish we would have actually gotten to see more details of the investigation. It would have been nice to see how Kirigiri actually got all the answers/evidence/deductions she did? Like I get she's supposed to be mysterious and super skilled but dang you can let the audience know a little bit more from time to time.


It definitely felt a bit like "just waiting for the next death" but I never got bored.


The part that annoyed me the most and felt was the lowest part of the story was the ending. There was a major plot twist and whatnot (oh snap apocalypse of despair?? what did that mean? I didn't know until watching all the other Danganronpa animes), but I honestly had a super hard time figuring out what they even meant and wasn't able to comprehend it until after I spent roughly half an hour going through the Danganronpa wiki to get a basic idea. Like I didn't understand all the talk about "despair" or grasp how serious it was?? It made little sense to me.

I am not great at seeing plot twists in advance but this one was a huge amount of information in the last...2 episodes I think?? It definitely felt rushed. 


Art:  7/10


Thought it was fine, I'm not really fussy with animation styles unless its something like random 3d animation that looks really awkward and stuff although the style they used for the executions was certainly different...I think it was effective though how it managed to freak me out more then if the style had stayed the same.


There were bits where mouths opening seemed really stiff etc?? but I guess you gotta budget lol


Sound: 7/10


I actually really liked the first opening, "Never Say Never" it was really fun to hear and the mixture of rap and singing worked well. The second opening, "Monokuma Ondo" I didn't really care for the style of, I guess I just don't really like hearing him sing lol 


The ending, "Zetsubōsei: Hero Chiryōyaku" was also pretty good, I like how high paced it became. 

Nothing super memorable, although I liked the first opening pretty good.

I've heard worse and more boring openings and endings.


Characters: 5/10


I'm definitely not the first(or even in the first hundred I'm sure) to comment on how in such a short anime with so many characters, theres not going to be enough time to develop them. 


Even Naegi felt pretty basic "super optimistic protagonist" and I didn't feel he ever got much motive nor did his attachment to some character that we never saw him interact with much or at all. I've since read on how in the games the majority of gameplay involves interacting with fellow students and that would make sense for Naegi to feel attached...but I guess it was doomed to be hard to execute in this format and it shows.


Just...it wasn't horrible but not good either.


Enjoyment: 6/10


Premise was interesting enough to keep me watching to the end, characters were just average, art wasn't bad nor great, I liked the pink blood and thought it was a nice choice, the story was fine till the end in my opinion. 


Overall: 7/10


Not the best anime or the worst, I did enjoy it fairly well until the end. Worth a watch if you like the premise and don't mind a story that totally twists and become hard to understand at the end.

Fifteen students, each with different skills, are trapped in a killing game at their school, Hope’s Peak Academy. To escape the game, one is supposed to kill one or two of their fellow students and get away with it. Things will not be so easy though, as sometime after a murder, there will be a class trial. If everyone deduces the culprit’s identity correctly, only the culprit will die and the game continues. Otherwise, they all die except for the culprit and the culprit wins.
The concept of a killing game with a trial (thanks Ace Attorney for getting me hooked into trials) system was reallyexecuted well. The drawback to DR: The Animation was that it was adapted from a game, hence quite a significant amount of content was cut out, though they have most of the points down but just quite summarized. I loved how Kirigiri Kyouko was at first introduced as “Super Duper High School ???”, since it served as a hook for me because I had hoped that they would tell us what ??? was. They did at the end, but not going to say what it is. Each character was also very different and unique in their own way. I could go on but there are so many characters to cover. Yet it was quite surprising for me to see that they could interact quite well. \n\n
Overall, great show but considerably bad adaptation. I would recommend playing Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, the game that this was adapted from. But I had started with the anime first and imo it also served as a good experience, just that starting with the game might give you the best experience.

Wow... This was a crazy show. It was was sick, f***** up, and insane, but mostly awesome. I enjoyed this anime becuase it was unordinary. Pitting students against each other in a death match, crazy right. Aside from the story, the artwork was very good. It featured cool, creative animated scenes when ever some one was on the "Chopping Block". The characters were crazy, you had your typical nice kid who was against the killing, and some kids who were all for it. The drama and betrayal were interesting to watch. With twists along the way, this show managed to make me interested enough tobinge the entire thing in a day or two. I really recommend it! I still get goosebumps thinking about it!

First of all, I should issue a disclaimer: everyone should probably play the game first, then watch this afterwards.
Danganronpa: The Animation has the potential to be outstanding, but its rushed runtime of only 12 episodes prevents it from living up to its potential. The plot is excellent, and the trials are a blast to watch, but with the investigative period crammed into about 30 seconds each time, and no time to really get to know or care about the supporting characters, everything that happens is just meaningless action. If the producers wanted to pace this properly, they would have extended the show's run to 18episodes, with the extra time devoted to exploring the characters and their interactions (utilizing notable "free time" material from the game) and the investigations, giving the viewer greater access to the vital evidence beforehand in order to begin puzzling out the mysteries for themselves.


Even being rushed, however, the story watches like a fairly gripping crime drama on TV, and there are enough well played twists to keep you guessing. The writers seem to revel in subverting traditional tropes and cliches, and what happens is often not at all what you'd expect. Also, the music is excellent, with a great opening and ending, as well as fantastic atmospheric music in the background. That one opening with the "Monokuma Song" was rather odd though.


Overall, I'd definitely recommend this to anyone that enjoys crime/mystery shows, but with the caveat that they play the game first so that they have a more in depth experience to begin with, and also so they don't know the "whodunnit" beforehand.

I enjoyed the anime and somewhat enjoyed the game, if you are, for lack of a better word, triggered by that statement, please stop reading this.
Now that's out of the way, let's continue.
Let's talk about how I got to the anime anyway. I heard about the game and actually began to watch a playthrough of the game, however I just grew bored because of how much pretty much every single thing was dragged out. Because of this, I took the easy way out and watch the anime instead. However I'm sure the game was great, it's just a bit too wordy and slow-paced than Iprefer.


I think one of the reasons this anime gets so much criticism is just because it's an adaptation of the game. It's not 100% accurate, go figure, but think of it this way, if the anime kept every single little thing it had in the game, then the anime would be 50+ episodes long. That's probably an exaggeration, but please bear with me. This is a turn-off for a lot of people, including myself. Remember how I said this was the easy way out? Some people prefer their anime around ten or twenty episodes, mainly because they either have busy lives, short attention spans, or just prefer things go straight to the point. Because of this, the creators would loose a good bit of potential customers just because of that. So I'm glad they shortened it.


However, there's also a few cons to shortening it. There isn't as much character development or any time to get to know the characters. This I don't really like, I feel like they could've extended the episodes to maybe 24 episodes if they showed more interactions with the characters from the game, so I agree with most criticism there.


The art was gorgeous, however I HATED that they simply reused the execution scenes from the game. It was such a cheap copout. I thought they were going to do their own adaptation of the infamous scenes, but they decided not to. I'd rather not think it was laziness because if the creators were truly lazy, they wouldn't have made the anime anyway. Maybe it was for budget problems or they just didn't think it was necessary? I don't know. Other than that, the art was great.


The characters were either intriguing, annoying, or uninteresting altogether. I didn't really find an in between. Because of this, I found it a bit difficult to care for characters that either got executed or murdered. In fact, I only truly liked about four characters. Again, I think if the anime extended a bit, I think I would've gotten a better understanding of the characters and liked them a bit more.


The voice acting was actually quite nice, I don't think there was much room, if any, for improvement there.


In conclusion, I enjoyed this anime very much. It may not be in my top five of all time, but I would definitely recommend it if you want a dark story full of action, betrayal, and, most of all, bloody demises. However, if you're a huge fan of the game, I'd definitely either keep an open mind or skip this anime altogether.

(WARNING: this review has spoilers that contain information on the second and third episodes, though don't be discouraged about reading if you want a detailed review!)
Pre-review Statement;
Danganronpa is more-or-less a murder mystery genre in it's own twisted way. Playing with his puppets, the master sure has whipped up a sick fancy to gore!
     Think of this anime as the cop show NCIS, except animated with fifteen-year-old "students" as the suspects and investigators—even the victims. This series is most definitely "mystery" and "horror" at it's clear finest, and even finding the opportunities to throw in a little comedy to lift the spirits after a gruesome execution. Though,if you fancy romance and fantasy more than being neutral when it comes to genre, walk away—this is filled with teenagers who're on edge backstabbing one another; literally.\n\n
     For example, about the backstabbing; Sayaka Maizono attempts to trick her friend from middle school, Makoto Naegi, into being blamed into murder which after she horrifically failed to act upon, which later was hypothesized to "save him" from having to live out the nightmarish murder party, which, as said, is only a theory to what her true intentions were... Y'know, because she died. Nevertheless, after that, killing after killing occurred, friend going against friend in a ruthless attempt to escape from Hell on Earth. (Again, terribly sorry for including a spoiler. I was only looking for one example!)\n\n
     The reason I liked this anime was because it wasn't cliché like a lot of other anime are in some sense, and it's unique way of getting the viewer engaged in the investigations that commence after a murder—not just the characters. The writer of the original manga did an excellent job in executing that; making the viewers/readers of the anime/manga think instead of just watching/reading. Not only that, but it also has a deep depth of detail that is also commendable. The story is very original, as said, and the way the characters act upon are also unique. And for Christ's sake, it even has it's own intro and outro songs! Some other anime have this, but most of them don't. The song's themselves are also very rememberable! \n\n
     In all review, everything about this anime is great to me. Everyone has their own tastes in anime, and though this one lacks fantasy, or other desired genre types, Danganronpa can be very addicting to watch after a couple of episodes! Overall, in every aspect, I give this anime a straight "10" for it's excellence!

One thing is when you play the game first, then watch the anime. Another thing is when you watch the anime first, then play the game.
For all who played the game first, good job, because this anime is the spoiler version of the game, including the texts and bullets appearing on the screen on class trials, and similar. And the story was great, but unfortunately it had more plot twists for me than the game.
Comparing to the game, the art and animation is really bad, I honestly think the art is a little lazy-made and the animation is more lazy-made.
The voices and characters were reallygood, the background music is very awesome, also only a little of the voices sound annoying at times, or even usually. Talking about the characters, it's really fun to make fanart since the designs are unique and the colors are good chosen. The personalities and backstories are also good, except that some of the backstories are either rushed up or the ideas in them are overused.\n\n
I enjoyed watching this anime, mainly because of the game. All the reasons above might explain why i give this anime a 9/10.

***THIS IS A SPOILER FREE REVIEW***
Danganronpa Kibou no Gakuen to Zetsubou no Koukousei The Animation (holy fu@# what a mouthful of a title) was a wildcard anime for me this past season. When I watched the first episode I had no idea if I was going to end up liking my investment. I am pleased to announce that I did end up enjoying the show even if the ending was pretty boring.
Story: 5/10
So the plot was pretty intriguing in the beginning. The anime follows the main protagonist Naegi as he and the other highschool students struggle to survive in the crazy dog eat dog worldthey find themselves in. Every episode follows a monster of the week type format where there is a murder each episode that the students have to solve and vote on. I rather enjoyed this aspect of the plot; to see what alliances formed between the cast and how each one responded to being called guilty. I would say that the one thing that really hurts this anime is how predictable the future events are to see coming. It was quite obvious to me who killed each person in each episode (except for the last one). Even though it was predictable, I still ended up enjoying most of the show. The ending however really let me down; don’t want to spoil it so all I’ll say is that it felt very melodramatic and rushed. I have heard that the anime was very faithful to the game it was based on so props for that.


Animation: 9/10


LOVED THE EYES IN THIS ANIME. Yeah the animation was very spot on in every episode as the character models were very defined and seemed quite unique compared to any other anime I have seen. If I had to complain about anything it would be how a lot of the miscellaneous objects off camera center seemed very undefined.


Sound: 8.5/10


Liked the soundtrack and thought the voice actors did a great job. Shout out to the voices of Togami and Kirigiri. Not so much Naegi he just came off pretty pathetic for most of the show.


Characters: 5/10


To put it bluntly, every character in this anime is some stereotype of another show already out. You have the super shy, sportsy tomboy, larger nerd type person, ext. There are some good moments between the characters but the only developing friendship you become aware of is between Naegi and Kirigiri. The cast did work well with each other though so some points have to be given there.


Overall: 6.9/10


The show was pretty enjoyable. It had an interesting start and went off like a rocket. It did start to lose some steam once people started dying off and I still think it could have ended better but that is just my opinion. I recommend this if you like detective style anime.


Enjoyment: 6/10


Thanks for reading my review! If you liked my writing style, would like to see some other reviews, or just want to talk, please stop by my page!


Sincerely,

Awesome Drummer

This review does not contain spoilers. I have not played the games and I do not intend to since I have no time and do not own a playstation so this review will not compare the anime with the games. 
First the art is quite interesting in style and colors, however there are a lot of static images throughout the series, making it look awkward at times. Character design is unique also. 
The story is interesting, however, it leaves you with a few questions which I think will be answered in the sequel. The mystery side and the trials are interesting to watch, but youcan't figure out the solution on your own since you don't have all the clues.  Sometimes it feels rushed (especially when presenting clues) that you need to go back and re-watch to understand. 


Characters as I said are unique in design, however from a psychological point of view (since it's rated as a psychological anime) do not really make sense. Some aspects are taken to lightly (like betrayals, friendship) and characters recover easily without caring about what psychological torment they went through. 


The music is not that good, however the Japanese voice acting is good, I really liked some of the characters voices. 


Overall I really enjoyed watching this, the only problem is the shallow character development and the static art at certain points.

Danganronpa is a series that was rated as "good" by Anime News Network's users. 
This series is really fascinating, because during the whole anime I wanted to know what was going to happen next 100% of the time. The suspense and the mystery are really well done and make the viewer willing to see the next episodes. Even if the plot is not extraordinary, the way it is written achieved to make this series very interesting and worth seeing. The soudtrack behind this gives goosebumps and I think that it is one of the strengths of this series. The characters are very differents one fromanother, each with their own capacities, specialities and personality, which make the anime very rich and keeps it from being redundant and boring. The main character, Naegi, is the most interesting because the way he evolves and finds himself some talents through the series is very interesting. The animation is good, but isn't extraordinary. That's why this series deserves a rating of 8 on 10.

Before I start bear in mind that the only thing I know about the game is that many people say it's better than the anime.
Dangan Ronpa is a survival game anime where 15 of the super duper elite students are trapped inside Hope's Peak Academy and the only way for them to escape is to kill someone, it doesn't end at that though. After each murder, a trial is held where the students try to find the killer. If the killer is found, he/she is executed, however if the killer isn't, all other students are executed instead.
The soundtrack and artstyle are definitely the anime's strengthpoints; the music especially does an omega good job at setting the tone for the situation and the artstyle is distinguishable from every other anime. The characters have great personalities, some way more generic than the others, but you'll find yourself picking favorites. On the other hand, what holds the anime back is that everything seems rushed; the investigations are super short and not in depth and the characters aren't explored enough, which I'm sure isn't the case in the original game.\n
All in all; Dangan Ronpa would've been way better if the anime was 24 episodes instead of 13, however it's still a super fun experience.\n
Overall Rating: 78%\n
My anime reviewing blog: 300wordsanimereviews.blogspot.com

I found this anime...a bit of a let down.
I will use the same format as my last review, using the rating system to help structure my review.
Before I begin I would like to disclaim that I have not played the video game, I do intend to, but at this time this is the opinion of someone who has only seen the anime.
When I first began the anime, I didn't really know what to expect. I hadn't really researched it before hand, and I didn't know it would take the same twist it did. As soon as the plot was revealed, I was drawn in immediately.If you read my review on Mahou Shoujo Madoka Magica, you would know that I quite like anime that take a turn in the opposite direction of how you first imagine it. The premise of the story is quite interesting, and the idea isn't an overused trope like other anime of the same genre. However, when I reached a certain point closer to the end of the anime, I realised that there wasn't enough time to finish the story in a way that I had hoped it would and I found the ending very disappointing. I am a big fan of revisiting anime that I have previously watched and enjoyed, but with an ending like this one I can't see myself doing that. I cannot delve into what disappointed me most about the ending without spoiling things, so I will leave it with this. I felt the conclusion wasn't as thought out as the rest of the story, and I felt like there was far more room for improvement and suspense in the ending.


Next, the art. I was absolutely blown away with the use of mixed styles in the anime. I fell in love with the use of almost paper-like animation in some of the execution scenes. Absolutely brilliant! The style in the rest of the anime I found a little bit average, nothing really jumped out at me like in others I have watched. However, that being said, I adored the design of the characters. They were all very unique and I quite enjoyed all their little details that belonged only to them. I liked how the designer branched into all different ideas, like the super muscly girl or the sexy goth. The use of the varying designs also helped mask whom the murdered was every episode. You couldn't use any stereotypes to help you figure it out, because there were too many to analyse. I was surprised every time!


In my opinion, there isn't much to talk about in regards to the sound. The opening of the anime, Never Say Never, was very catchy and hip. The ending, Zetsubousei: Hero Chiryouyaku, I felt was a little dull.

The music used in investigations and punishments didn't stand out to me especially, probably because I was too busy trying to figure out who was the murderer then trying to recover after realising I was wrong. 

Okay, that's probably a lie. I personally don't have too much of an opinion on the music. It was...alright. I wish I could say more.


Now I stated earlier that I loved the character design in this anime, but as far as character personalities and development I found it bone dry. I understand that the intent wasn't for the students to get close and become buddies, but I found the characters quite boring without any kind of real development. I like to relate to my characters in some way, whether it's because Tsukino Usagi (Sailor Moon) is a big crybaby like me, or because all Kaneki Ken (Tokyo Ghoul) wants is to fit in somewhere like me, or because Izumi Konata (Lucky Star) has itty bitty boobies just like yours truly - I still have one aspect that I share with a character and it helps me to almost connect with the mangaka and share how they feel about their character. Relating to a character I think is an important aspect of any story telling. The characters in this anime were all very boring to me and it made their deaths a little less intense for me.


Overall, I did like the anime. But there were particular aspects that made the whole weekend I spent binging it seem a little less exciting. If even a few of these aspects were met, I think that this anime could have been in my top 10 favourite. Again, if you read my other review, you would know I am a bit of a hard judge when it comes to my favourite anime.

It's hard for me to recommend this anime, but if you're the kind of person that likes horror but have a bit of a weak stomach, the horror is mellowed out by the use of discolouration of the blood. If you're also like me and enjoy unexpected twists, this would meet your criteria.


I hope you enjoy this anime a bit more than I did. Sadly, I have to rate this at a 4 sakura flowers out of 10.

This is an anime adaptation of a game that has been squashed into 13 episodes which I will admit was quite disappointing. This story is about special high school students that are the best in their niche. The range and diversity of talents that these kids have has been quite entertaining. We've got: super duper scion, super duper swimmer, super duper baseball star, super duper gang leader etc. The character design is both intriguing and cute, if you're looking for a gory anime because the synopsis is about murder then I hope you don't mind pink blood. (It was to keep the ratings down, don'thate the awesome producers :3) 


Komaeda Naegi has been chosen by 'chance' to enter Danganronpa high school, little did he know the good ratings were all propaganda... he is thrust into a dark room and is awoken naturally by his conscience. He then somehow (lol) makes his way to the gym where all the super dupers are to meet. A lot of friendly and unfriendly characters greet him. Head of the school is a black and white bear (Monobear) Who tells them that they'll be trapped in this school forever and if they want to graduate then they must murder someone. LET THE PSYCHOLOGICAL GAME COMMENCE!!! This story is not super dark though I'd say give it to kids over 8 so they'll be able to mentally prepare for a few twists and surprises here and their. 


I like the anime because it's what I've been searching for ever since I found anime <333

In light of Danganronpa 3 anime coming out (and before anyone ask, no you did miss a 2 cause there wasn't one...don't ask please) I decided to review danganronpa the anime because it (and I need to get some reviews for anime I like) Let's do this.
Story- 
The story is decently adapted which I am happy about because if they didn't adapt this atleast decently I would be pissed to no end. But in the end it was decently adapted. Granted it suffered from being rushed especially with investigations and trials (which improved going to the end due to less people being alive at thetrials as the show goes to a close). I normally don't care about amount of episodes but this was a case where in could have at least used about 20+ episodes instead of just 13 and it would be a little better.


Another issue this adaption suffers from is character development in the story. Because of the short length, unlike the game where you could hang out and talk with the characters to know them better, here...not so much. I mean that is probably an issue to be expected especially when they are adapting a game that can take up to hours and days to complete depending on how you play video games. It didn't help that the episode amount was short. The characters developed but not like in the game because when characters died in the anime it not like you have a huge attachment to them or anything and it is easy to shrug off.


Due to pacing issues and mediocre to subpar character development I have to give the story a 6/10


Art- The art is fine. Pretty much match up the character designs to the game which I am happy about and I have really no major complaints about it minus how it could look stilted sometimes to be honest. 7/10


Sound- The highest point for me. I loved the opening to this anime. I just do. The ending is fine and seeing that I watched both sub and dub I honestly liked both. Granted the english dub sounded weird to me at times, it was good. 8/10


Character- Sadly unlike the Persona 4 anime, I didn't care as much for these characters unlike I did in the game. My favorites by far is Junko and Monokuma, especially Monokuma though granted his voice annoyed me in the English dub to the point of almost urging me to mute my tv while I watched it. Overall the characters get a 7/10 which is really me just being generous and a little bias cause this show gave me a new favorite in the villains category in anime.


Enjoyment- I enjoyed myself with this anime and had a real good time watching it despite its issues.


Overall- Danganronpa isn't the best adaption of a video game but it is one of the better one. It obviously has the pacing issues which doesn't help with it short length and it probably could have benefited being longer then it was. Overall I really did enjoy myself watching this so I am going to give this anime an 7.5/10. If your looking to watch a video game adaption. This is one I recommend 


That being said, peace people

I think that this anime could have been bit better. The game was able to display the story a lot better than the anime was, I think this is due to the fact that it was shortened. I think that there wasn't alot of character growth and that it would probably have been a bit harder to follow if I hadn't played the game. I think that the anime itself would have been much better if they had stuck in 6 or so more episodes that way the characters would have been able to develop and each event would have had more time to unfoldbefore the next one came along. Overall it was still nice to watch and I still love the art style's unique twist. 


(please note this is my first review I'm so sorry if this is awful)

    Constructive Criticism: Could have used more episodes.

Where do I even begin with this anime?
I think I'll start off by saying, this anime is really only for people who are fans of the game.  If you don't play the game or at least read/watch a walkthrough then you will be generally clueless to the characters or the way that gather evidence go.  The anime skips a lot of key points when it comes to gathering the evidence.
Sixteen characters and thirteen episodes was never a good idea, giving each character a three episode arc, and then boom, they are dead.  It is hardly enough time to characterize them. This leavesthe watcher apathetic and noncaring towards most of them because we simply don't know much about them beyond the scope of what the anime entails.

The prime example is Leon Kuwata.  There is a lot of characterization in the game that is missed in the anime.  For instance, while he is the super high school level baseball player/all star, he desired to change his super high school title to rock star, and thus his appearance changed greatly.


  This isn't even explained in the anime, and you get two different renders of his character.  If you watch the first episode you merely think it's a generic baseball player even though the other characters are shown as they currently look.  Nothing about Leon's character was explained.  Instead of the character talking about his hopes and dreams and conflicting feelings between his super high school levels, he's delivered generic lines.  When his trial comes (it being two of the most emotional trials in the game/anime in my opinion) the character has a mental break down, but we do not feel the same as watchers as we would playing the game because this information is left out.  The delivery of emotion is simply not the same and the character looses value.


No one can feel sorry for characters they don't get attached to, no matter how emotionally impacting a trial is supposed to be.

This was originally based off a video game, as far as I know. A game that was about detecting crimes and stuff. This anime definitely shows signs of that. I happen to really like this piece however, just because its completely mental. Its very different and seemingly grim in a childish world. Blood, happens to be bright, neon pink, and all the characters are crazy. Not much else is too special though. The ending was ridiculously cheesy and still doesn't make much sense to me at the end. But I did really like this anime for the craziness within it.

Danganronpa: Kibou no Gakuen to Zetsubou no Koukousei - The Animation.
Which can only mean it is..a game adaptation. Now, I have NOT played the game. So, I will be reviewing it just for the anime.
By the way, this is my first review. So, yeah.
Story [8/10]
     I'm going to be honest, I loved how fast paced this was. It was what I was looking for for a while now. For every episode, there is either a new murder case or another of the infamous Classroom Trial. New mysteries lead to more questions and sometimes make me wonderwhat could happen next or how could this lead to that, making that mysterious atmosphere. Then, the Classroom Trial comes and after figuring out all the clues and missing pieces, someone still had to die in the end. All because of a teddy bear. (This anime or the game is not recommended for the little of age.)


    But, if there is one negative thing I have to say about the story, it is that it felt rushed to me(will be discussed in the enjoyment section).


Art [8/10]

     Switching from 2-D to 3-D and back again was definitely news to me and though the 2-D aspect was not the best-looking, the 3-D part of it stood out to me, sort of. For the most part, the art is solid and the animation is smooth but it is not always constant, being that it is not clear sometimes. The characters are quite solid and a little simplistic(how I like it), but, again, is not always constant. (By the way, the fact that the blood is pink in this anime made the victims look awkward.)


Sound [6/10]  

      For the sound and music aspect of this anime, it is not anything particularly special. Certain music would play at the right time sometimes, and sometimes, not so much. The sound, to me, were more average than good. 


     The opening and the ending wasn't anything that stood out to me either.  Although, the opening did surprise me with it's English lyrics and it sounded decent so, it was not all bad. Overall, it isn't very memorable for me in any way.


Character [7/10]

     Being introduced to 16? characters of the anime right off the bat was a bit overwhelming for me and trying to remember every single name so I don't get confused was a bit of a chore at first. However, as I got to know characters like the optimistic Naegi Makoto or the ever-so-mysterious Kyouko Kirigiri, it turned out to be less confusing than I first thought. From average people like Sayaka Maizono and Leon Kuwata to people who have...other agendas like Monokuma him?self made it interesting for me.


     Now, the main problem with this anime is that there isn't enough character development. Most characters either don't change or hardly change at all. The reason lies within the fact that there just isn't enough 'space' to put in that character development(which I will discuss in the next section).


Enjoyment [7/10]

     Alright, I'm at the bottom of the bucket and I have but 3 words. Not. Enough. Episodes. This is where the problem of the anime lies. The plot definitely felt rushed to a point where I don't even get what I'm trying to figure out from the story and,  since they are following a game, even just putting the plot into 13 episodes seems to leave, literally, no room for a filler episode or even some decent character development. Just saying.


     I'm not saying it's all bad since this was the kind of thing I was looking for in a long time. A good fast-paced anime with some sort of mystery aspect to it. The whole thing about hope and despair was cheesy, but I was okay with it. Survival was also a big concept considering there's lots of blood(pink) in this...and lots of dying too, which I also enjoy in a show.


Overall [8/10]

     I don't exactly have much complaints over this anime except that there isn't enough episodes to go around. But, overall, the thirteen weeks I spent to watch this anime was, more or less worth it in my opinion. So, if there will be an anime adaptation for the sequel of the first game this was adapted from, I am definitely hoping it will be better than this one...and more episodes. DEFINITELY more episodes.

As a fan of the game as well as its sequel, I came into this not expecting much to be honest.
The games are a masterpiece of no other in my opinion, that being said something such as this can't transition to the likes of a 13 episode series all too well.
However that being said I see it more of an add on to the game.
It's wonderful to see all of the scenes animated rather than using sprites with the occasional single imaged event.
Story: 9/10 The story as a whole is wonderful, but being put into a 13 episode slot was visibly a hard job. Alot of things were either left out or put in with little effort.


Art: 5/10 You can tell instantly that it was rushed. Certain scenes are almost laughable how rushed they are! It still shines in other areas however, so once you get away from the awkward in betweens you'll notice a lot of well executed scenes (pun intended).


Sound: 10/10 The original sound is most likely my favorite soundtrack of all time. A lot of the tracks for this have been slightly altered, but not too much to ruin any enjoyment. In addition to this, the end theme is a great song alone as well being completely fitting (lyrics wise).


Character: 4/10 Obviously with 13 episodes they couldn't pack a lot of character development into this. Coming out of the series someone could completely misinterpret the characters as a whole. They get the main point across but forget the rest most of the time.


Enjoyment: 8/10 As I mentioned before I personally think of it more as an 'add on'. That being said it's wonderful to watch! However its almost laughable how fast the trials go. The days of screaming at your PSP to get the characters to understand the situation is far behind us, but instead we have a bunch of genius' figuring everything out faster than the original investigation! Other than that, it's always a pleasure to see our favorite scenes animated.


Bottom line: Don't watch this unless you've played the game.
