Dangan Ronpa is a surreal mystery-series, one with a premise and presentation that most audience-members will either accept or reject on sight. 
The design and animation is filled with high contrasts and exaggerated ideas bordering on the cartoonish, pink-colored blood and extravagant execution-scenes being two examples. Being based on a visual novel game, the show borrows visuals from the source-material diligently to the point where you’re looking at bits of gameplay in certain parts. In that sense Dangan Ronpa can look like a jarring mess, or like a buffet of intersting visual choices.
The soundtrack is as varied and random as the gallery of characters andtheir personalities. Relentless rock n’ roll and erratic electrical instruments play up the quirky and unstable atmosphere, somber tunes from pianos and keyboards lend themselves to some sadder moments as well as the almost dream-like setting.


As a detective-story surrounding a death-tournament, one should go in expecting numerous character-deaths. Combine this with the fact that the series is only thirteen episodes long, and it becomes apparent that very little time is spent on character-development and fleshing out. Thankfully the many quirks and the style of the show make every character distinctive. In the show's defense, if you have more than a dozen characters to play detective with, and an equal number of episodes to do it with, then making the cast into caricatures is the best approach. There simply is no time to develop them beyond a few bonding scenes. Despite not having deep characters, their personalities are entertaining, and more often than not the show is self-aware of the clichés it uses.


The mysteries are truly the main focus and the greatest selling-point of Dangan Ronpa. An episode will usually start off by showing a murder and the clues left behind, and then have the mystery solved in the next episode. The show succeeds on this point by giving the audience time to think for themselves about each murder-case, giving a fair chance to untie the knots of an eccentric world, some solutions being simple while others are more far-fetched.


Dangan Ronpa's greatest strengths and flaws are in its contrasting presentation and premise. It is a series that most will either love or hate while watching it. Recommended to fans of murder-mysteries who also enjoy the crazier and more chaotic side of anime.

For the record, i have not played the game and therefore speak for the anime only. 
Story: 3/10: There are two types of mytery: the one that gives the clues necessary for the audience to put the pieces together and the danganronpa mystery, which involves hiding those clues to the audience so they wont figure things out.
 A good mystery would provide those clues in a discrete way so when the mystery is revealed you would look back at it in surprise and ask yourself why you could not figure it out sooner, because the clues were there. Instead, Danganronpa decides to show us onlythe irrelevant, and instead of giving us a hint of anything before the trial they leave it to the characters to narrate us all their discoverings instead of letting the audience figure them out for itself, thus creating 0 interest in me while watching it. In other words: Danganronpa is not unpredictable, it´s just impossible to predict and therefore fails as a mystery. 


Art: 7/10: the character designs are nice and i think the animation is pretty nice, especially the way the punishment scenes where animated which i though it was an artistic and very creative way to not make them so graphic and bloody.


Sound: 6/10: i think the music fits well in the scenes, but i cant recall almost nothing of it so it's not so memorable. The ending song though, it´s awesome.


Character: 3/10: unfortunately, good character design does not mean good character development. There is only so much it can be told from the appearance, the rest is up to how the characters are portrayed and how much of their personality can be seen through their actions. The only thing i can say for them can be summarized in one word: shallow. Having a bg cast and considering the first ones to die did not have enough time to shine, i expected to have some lack of characterisation, but even the main characters where shallow. Though some of their past was revealed, it meant nothing becaus i still felt i was looking at the surface of what could have been deep characters. Nothing of the way they feel is mentioned,  most of them faced death so calmly it was obvious they were not real. If they tried at least to make them react to the dangerous situation they were in as a normal human being, the series could have been so great even with it's shitty mystery. 


Enjoyment: 5/10: honestly, i only kept up with the series for two reasons: to see the punishment scenes and to find out who would die next at the hands of whom, and because a friend of mine was pushing me. Everything apart from death and torture scenes was a blurr to me, none of the "content" the series was trying to offer sticked into my head, so this is for me just and empty series with some cool killing scenes and nothing else. 


Overall: 5/10: i would only recommend it if you are so bored out of your mind, sooooooo bored, you are willing to stand it for some 2 minutes of tortures with great animation style.

In some ways its the classic find-the-killer mystery. But not only do the kids have play "who done it" but they also have to figure out who the mastermind is. The situation they are in amplifies the suspense.
The art was cool. The dramatization of the blood was unique and fit well into the story. The art does change when it comes to punishment time but it was still good art. Each character was very much different from the rest and I never really mixed any of them up.
There are a couple of unexpected surprises but they work into the story and make the characters moreround rather then the flat stereotypical ones they seem to be in the beginning.\n\n
In the very beginning I wasn't really sure what was the actual opening and ending but after a couple of episodes I got it. I liked the ending, the first time I heard it, I thought it was Vocaloid but its Soraru.\n\n
I did not play the game but I was still able to enjoy Danganronpa and overall liked it.

This is...an interesting one.
This is Danganrompa.
Let me preface this by saying that, like the average viewer, it seems, I've never played the game. From my understanding, however, this anime is modeled by a perfect runthrough of the game, which is way longer than the 13-episode long anime. It's best that we look at this on a more surface level.
And there's a lot on the surface, but barely anything underneath.
STORY: 6/10
Boy goes to new school he's never heard of. Boy meets girl from his past. Boy and girl find out that the school is far more sinister than they one percieved, so boy and girl teamup to fight against potential evil while forming alliances with side characters that are as terrifed as them. A simple premise done fairly, but is still lacking.


I will give props to the anime for being not-so predictable. As the summary states, it's a murder mystery, and like any good mystery, it's difficult to tell who actually committed said murder/s. You don't know these character's origins or reasoning until it becomes important. The school is so vast, like a perilous chasm. The anime does a really good job extending themselves from the Scooby Doo level of storytelling.


And yet, like Scooby Doo, it's still basic.


Let me explain.


As stated, this anime follows a perfect run of the game, which seems to be one of the many common complaints of the show. That's understandable. The main character, (the Pheonix Wright or Professor Layton problem solver, if you will,) knows exactly on cue when a character is lying during a "trial," where the characters present must crack down on who murdered the victim of the week. He barely needs any hints and minimal assistance from other characters, basically ceasing any tension during the actual trial. It doesn't leave the viewer much time to participate, like a classic mystery should. Rather, it's like we're witnessing the trial, more like a speedrun, which frankly sucks as the strongsuit of the anime is its build-up.


ART: 8/10


Frankly, it's fantastic. The show is very stylized, and the character designs were so bright and expressive. It has this very "The World Ends With You" vibe, where each character looks urbanized and exaggerated.


Also, this show is really good at displaying emotions and making the viewer feel certain ways from color schemes and certain aspects of scenery. The trial room is intimidating. The punishment scenes make you feel this air of hopelessness for the character facing execution, no matter how much you may have hated them previously.


The animation is fluid and its aesthetic is rather distinct. Not many complaints here.


SOUND: 8/10


One common praise behind this anime is the music. Intro, outro, interludes. All wonderful, and I don't have much to say besides it does truly match the thematics of the show with this techno-rock vibe that's somehow chaotic and rhythmic at the same time...much like the show itself.


Also, I watched the dubbed version of this anime, so I can't say much of the sub. Will note, however, that the dub is astonishingly good.  It was very well casted, with some interesting choices for particular parts. You know that annoying blonde kid in Clannad? His voice actor voices the evil bear guy.


And he's damn GOOD.


And we're getting to that right now.


CHARACTERS: 6/10


Monokuma is perfect. Amazing. 10/10.


Everyone else? Eh.


We follow our main character, Naegi, who is generic anime boy who is moving into a new school where he will learn the importance of self-determinism and making sugoi-desu best friends. You should have stopped me if you've heard that one before.


We are also introduced to FIFTEEN new characters, (red flag,) whose number slowly goes down as students are killed and Monokuma, our main antagonist who moderates the murders, laughs at their plight. Very, very few of these fifteen are well-developed and interesting, and even so I can't remember the names of nearly any of them. Even by the final episode I was getting names mixed up; the only way I could remember who or what a character was was by appearance and trope. One could argue that's the point, but a problem while watching is still a problem.


There are some characters you learn literally NOTHING about, hence the problem behind this show being merely thirteen episodes; less than one episode per character. At times a murder feels more like an excuse to not give a character more screentime; soap opera ex machina, if you will. Only expressions and actions make them likable or memorable, but not quotable.


Except Monokuma. Shit, yo. 10/10.


ENJOYMENT: 7/10


I am so behind on my work because of this stupid show. I binge-watched over the course of two days, which was something I truly didn't expect. A friend introduced me to this show after she won a Monokuma plush from a grab-bag at a con and wanted to find its origins. It was really fun for me to watch with friends, and I observed more when I watched alone. I feel that, maybe if I watched the entire series with friends, I would have enjoyed the show much more.


It's humorous, if anything. I laughed a lot, and I felt the minimal amount of sympathy I was supposed to for those who were murdered or executed. I would feel much better if this show was more of a satire than a "horror mystery psychological thriller."


In other words, when I watched the rest of this show by myself, I realized this show was Phoenix Wright that tried too hard to be Professor Layton.


OVERALL: 7/10


This was surely one of the most dubious opinions I've ever had about an anime. Brilliant in some ways, desperately lacking in others. Perfect buildup, plenty anticlimaxes. Funny but not suspenseful like it really wanted to be. Needed more evil death bear.


Looking at these reviews, the opinions are completely polar: either the community thinks this is the worst thing to come out of the industry in this decade, or it's a godsend that leaves everyone on their toes. Personally, yeah, I thought this was good on a surface level. There were a lot of things I enjoyed, but what was missing was highly noticeable: an interesting protagonist, true conflict, true development that doesn't feel forced.


Basically, all I can say is this: go in with low expectations. And have fun.

Have you ever had an anime that you had such high hopes for that almost no matter what you just have to rate it high? Yeah, this is that anime for me. Was it as good as I hoped it would be? No. Did the ending disappoint me? Yes. So why did I rate it a 9 and even thought about rating it a 10? Because I loved the idea of this anime and the video game so much that I just had to.
The story is this anime's selling point. I mean 15 high school students trapped in an academy where they have to killeach other to get out? Who wouldn't find that interesting? The first episodes really had me going. I was always dying to know what would happen next. But then it turned into a pattern, someone dies, trial. Someone dies, trial. Even though trying to find out who the culprit was was exciting, I was like come on, more story, more plot! Then the last few episodes they gave me just that, rushing all the way, I mean why on earth did they try to cram everything into 13 episodes? 26 would be so much better! \n
The art was annoyingly meh. I mean they completely depended on the video game for everything, especially the deaths. I mean I can get how they can follow the video game but gosh it has no anime features, everything is from the video game.\n
The opening was strange, I didn't really like it and the ending was okay, video game like I suppose. I liked the voice actors so I that's why it gets an 8, oh and the soundtrack was good too.\n
The characters were the other selling point of this anime. I really love them all. It was so sad seeing them die one by one every week. They all had unique personalities and I found them very enjoyable. Especially the mastermind, which I won't say who. Oh and Monobear is adorable in an evil way. Great villain. \n
So despite the many setbacks I loved this anime anyways. Maybe it's because I had my heart set on wanting to like it so I just did. I am excited for the next season and will probably watch it and fans of the dangan ronpa video game should definitely watch the anime, it's worth it, not perfect at all, but worth it.

(Don't worry, this is spoiler free)
Story 9/10: Personally after finishing the entire Danganronpa franchise the story is absolutely brilliant. At the beginning it seems like an anime version of the Hunger games but there is so much more to it and all the games and anime seasons fit together like a puzzle pieces. 
Art 8/10: Out of every anime series I've seen and every manga series I've ever read, I've never seen such an art style ever before. Although there's not too much to it, it most certainly stands out.
Sound 9/10: Something I love about this series is the soundtrack. AND DAT OPENING AND ENDING!I think there was most certainly thought put into it, but I guess the credit shouldn't go to the anime makers because it is from the game. So it only gets a 9/10.


Characters 8/10: Every single one of the characters have very unique personalities causing them all to be memorable. It clearly took a lot of thought to be able to make such a creative cast.


Enjoyment five/10: The biggest disappointment in the Danganronpa anime is the fact that they ignored so much character development, and as someone who watched the anime first and then played the game, I couldn't remember anyone's name. A huge problem was they tried to fit about 2 hours of game play into just 12 episodes, causing so much information to be left in the dirt. 


Overall six/10: Danganronpa is a wonderful series, but not as an anime. If you are going to do anything towards this series, play the game. Because Danganronpa The Animation is a perfect example of a bad anime adaptation.

I'm just going to make this short as I can to get my point across. This came from an amazing visual novel and it was great from start to finish, though the problem is this adaptation. First lets talk about how this show was not nearly as long as it should have been. The trials alone took around 2 and a half to around 3 hours in the visual novel, yet in the anime here their impact, emotions, and stress the characters felt, all were almost nonexistent in this adaptation. While the story was roughly the same the characters did not get development at allpretty much as well as many other things were cut out as well. This should have been at least 26 to around 40 eps at least. The visual novel is great and definitely worth reading before this. I definitely would recommend that before this adaptation and if you still wanted to watch an anime version after then I would rec to watch this but only like that, otherwise this show just ruins the entire visual novels plot and cases. So in conclusion this should only be watched if you have completed the visual novel.

This is a spoiler free review:
Categories: Murder mystery, high school, genius, detective story, tragedy, despair.
This is a great murder mystery story based on a video game, though I have never played it. 15 students are locked in a school with no memory of how they get there and are told by their "principal" and captor, a very bipolar teddy bear character with a maniacal side, that to leave they need to kill each other and not get caught. After each murder or set of murders, the students are forced to gather and present evidence to determine who the murderer is and the murderers are putto some strange executions. The name of the anime means "To win (a debate/argument) with a bullet", which is in reference to the symbolic "bullets" or argumentative statements made by the main character in solving the cases. It's very well written and has a great plot and some genuine mystery that keeps you guessing. The art style is interesting and unique and most likely based on the video game and the characters are quite diverse in personality and appearance.\n\n
For anyone who likes a good mystery and a unique story set, I definitely recommend this, though people who've played the game don't seem to favor it.

I have never played the game, but if the game is as interesting as the anime I will find a way to get a copy, but enough of that lets get down to the anime. 
You start out with this simple thought that its going to be a high school slice of life anime with a young character name Naegi who gets accepted to the most acclaimed high school in all of Japan. Then you get ripped out of that idea and thrown into a world where 15 top students in there fields, locked up in the school they had tried to get in. Theysoon find out that they have no memory of what happened except the day they came to the school. Held captive by a mysterious figure who tells them "inorder to survive you have to kill your classmates and get away with it." 


If I had to compare this to anything its like Phoenix Wright meets Battle Royal. It also has this feel of a great crime investigation anime. In every episode it had me guessing on what the hell just happened, who killed who, and how are they going to find a way out of this. 


The characters are great as a group, but on there own they are weak, but thank god they are stuck together. I would complain more on how they call them Super Dooper so and so, yet it fits in within the show. The whole factor of you can't trust anyone has you at the edge of your seat. The music within the show makes it pulse bounding when the situation gets heated, but the opening theme is kind of weird like it tried to be like James Bond in the worst way and the ending theme is kind of okay the first time, but it is really catchy after the fifth time you hear it. 


The story could have gone on to full 26 episodes, yet it feels right that its short and sweet. Hardly no filler and gets straight to the point. I love this anime and glad to say that its a Masterpiece.

Well, this is, literally, the first anime I ever considered watching. My friends had been talking about Dangan Ronpa for a while, and it sounded like it was really very good. So I decided to try it for myself when the anime came out. And at first, I just pretty much watched the Anime. And I thought it was actually, really good. I had never watched anime before so I didn't know what to expect.
So the story was good, I thought the art was very cute, and the sound could've been better. Maybe it was just the streaming mirror I had decided to watch. Itprobably was. But I fell in LOVE with the characters. It was really nice and enjoyable, I liked it my first time watching it.


Then my friends had linked me to Oren's Let's Play. I didn't know Dangan Ronpa had started out as a game, but they told me that reading the Let's Play would probably end up being better than watching just the anime, and they were absolutely right. Don't get me wrong, the anime was still good! But reading the Let's Play and then watching the Anime, I realized they had left out quite a few of the pieces of the story. Like evidence, character backstory, and such.


I know it's the anime, and you can't spend a lot of time going around and talking to characters. And if you pick out certain characters, then some people may get angry. But comparing the game to the anime, the anime was more surface leveled than the game which you could really go in depth with.


So having that experience from reading the Let's Play (and soon, owning the game myself when it comes out!) the story had taken a little bit of a downfall. Especially since one of my favorite parts had been completely left out of the anime. Which also meant I enjoyed it less, but it was only a little bit less. It was still really fun to see how they had animated it, especially certain characters.


Overall, it's definitely something you should watch. But, if you have the chance, please please PLEASE go read Oren's Let's Play, because it makes it so much better and explains everything very well. It's a really good read and Oren actually has some notes on it that can help you better understand Japanese culture, save to mention actually getting to go through all the character's free-time events and get to know their character a little bit more.


(Let's Play is here: http://lparchive.org/Dangan-Ronpa/ )

Ok. I love the Dangonranpa games. But this is what you don't want in a video game adaptation.  First of all the voices I guess it kind of sounded like the original characters but I just hated some of the voices. Honestly no hate the voice actors but I just didn't like the way they adapted it.
 Second of all they crammed so much gameplay into a 13 episode series it felt so rushed and I just didn't like that. If it weren't so rushed I honestly would have enjoyed it a lot more. The art matched the original decently so I'll give themthat. I just didn't like this series and is your gonna do anything just play the games.

Remember my review for Baysona 4 the Cash-grab animation where I mentioned that many adaptations are very rushed and characters seem bland due to skipping major character development? Well, Danganronpa The Animation falls into that category of video game adaptations. The difference? It actually has an interesting, original concept and it is ambitious. Nonetheless, it falters a lot on all possible levels.
Michael Bay-sama would use an interesting concept and find as many ways as possible to milk everyone's money untill it runs dry and then move on to other concepts. To be honest, the producers tried to avoid this technique and seemed to care aboutthe source material since various mechanics from the original game are present. But, having to squeeze hours of content into a 1 cour series is a Herculean task and usually, despite the ambition behind a project, things go downhill as fast as    Hollywood producing shitty cliched romances, low-brow, unfunny comedies that people will overpraise more than they deserve and schlock action films. 


When the show starts, it is a classical "Whodunnit", Cluedo mime where everyone has to find the person who was murdered. But the interesting part starts when the classic Cluedo ends up being a battle royal of high schoolers organized by an anthropomorphic teddy bear whose merchandise you already have, but you will never admit it. And if this is not enough, the characters are all trapped in a high school for talented students where each one has their own unique talent/skill and the only way out is by killing each other. This already makes it stand out from your typical caliber of psychological, mystery anime and you have a promising start. So what went wrong?


Well, after a person is murdered, a trial is held after a specific time given for the students to search for clues where the students have to decide who is the murderer. The first ones were a delight to watch but later on they became very repetitive and the main protagonist is the only one who can figure everything out because everyone else is denser than Ichika in reasoning. To their credit, they kept trying to make each trial unique but this is how each one went: People suspect an innocent, Sherlock-kun (Naegi) thinks about it, the rest talk about bullshit, then Sherlock-kun guesses everything correctly and murderer gets executed in horrific ways. I am not joking. This is the formula that is repeated every time and the executions were good but later on they lacked the same punch they had as in the first few because characters are not developed properly ending up giving no shit about them. 


Speaking of characters, we all have to acknowledge the elephant in the room. The main protagonist, Sherlock-kun, is a scaredy character-less Macguffin who is the only one with actual brain cells in the whole show just because the plot demands it. White hair emotionless waifu (Kirigiri) is also smart but she is mostly useless and does nothing in the show to help. The rest range from ok to cringey. But, I really liked that they each represented a specific stereotype of a person and their appearance helped us understand more or less their main trait. I.e. Hifumi is an eroge-crazed otaku, Junko is your typical, spoiled, diva-esque model, Togami is your typical rich preppy brat that you want to kick his balls etc.

Although the characters are not terrible per se, they are very poorly used in the story and you feel absolutely nothing about most of the cast because the show does not give enough time to connect with them. 


The visual department is ok. The only thing I have to say is that the characters look weird and the producers pay great hommage to the game by adding mechanics present in the game and the executions look really creepy and horrific in a good way.


As for the auditory department, it was average. OST and ED were decent but the OP is terrible and irritating.


In conclusion you have an average anime that could have been better if handled with more care and it lasted longer. It is exactly like the first dish you cook in your life. It is not that bad but you could have done it better if you avoided some beginner traps and mistakes.


Overall: 5.58/10


Alternative recommendations:

-Mirai Nikki: Same mistakes but with less good visuals and better music.

-Death Parade: Instead of a battle royale, it has games where you risk your life and whoever loses will "die". Fate of the losers and winners is decided by a third person known as an arbiter. Great audiovisual experience although it falters a bit in the story and characters aspect in a similar manner as Danganronpa did.
